B00025ETIW|4.0|Had I not heard a huge buzz about My Chemical Romance's THREE CHEERS FOR SWEET REVENGE through music magazines and airplay of their second single, \\"HELENA\\", I probably wouldn't have given a second thought to purchasing this masterwork.  My Chemical Romance does something comparable to Green Day's rock opera, AMERICAN IDIOT--where Green Day made a political album about the condition of the U.S.A. and president Bush, MCR made a concept album about and containing themality concerning death.  Essentially, MCR is a combination of the emo/punk power of groups such as Weezer, Blink-182, Simple Plan, and etc... mixed with the ambitiousness of groups such as The Mars Volta and System of A Down.<br /><br />While death is certainly not my cup of tea when it comes to listening to and evaluating music, it made a very successful album here. While THREE CHEERS FOR SWEET REVENGE is under 40 minutes (39:44 to be exact), it is a positive length because the album has no filler material, which often plagues even the best of albums and artists.<br /><br />This album has few flaws, and most of the flaws aren't a big deal. On occasion, variation in key is somewhat of an issue; if you're a musician, you notice that My Chemical Romance drabbles a lot in d minor. While that key may be overused to an extent, as a band, MCR does sound good and polished in whatever key they choose play in.  Also, for musician's purposes only, you are happy when MCR chooses to change up the chord progressions and the consistent form of minor verse to major chorus throughout the album.  It isn't a big deal at all, but it is something that you notice.  A lot of songwriters have trouble trying not to write mearly chord progressions.  It is a hard feat to conquer from my own experience.<br /><br />Positive things about THREE CHEERS... is that Way has such nice gritty vocals that make you feel what the group is trying to convey to you.  Sometimes, even if you don't understand the depth behind the lyrics, the enthralling nature and emotion of Gerald Way's vocals suffices.  Also, no one can deny the emotion and dynamics of the driving guitar riffs and the background vocals themselves.  Here is my evaluation of each song:<br /><br />1. Helena-  my very favorite song from the album, this tune is both dark and beautiful at the same time.  It starts out with a whispered, mysterious, foreboding introduction by Way that breaks into the lead verse which is minoresque and dark with chilling background vocals at the bridge. Then the chorus ascends to major (bright).  A masterwork in itself, this is easily 5+/5.<br /><br />2.  Give 'Em Hell, Kid - embodies the typical elements of punk/emo with busy, heavy-driven guitar riffs.  Vocals once again are strong and the form remains the same as HELENA, though it isn't as exciting or moving as HELENA.  4/5<br /><br />3. To The End- another solid track that is more accessible and commercial than GIVE 'EM HELL KID, which is good in the sense that it is more commercial, but bad in the sense that it isn't as unique as say HELENA. 4/5<br /><br />4. You Know What They Do To Guys Like Us In Prison- once again excellent, gritty vocals by Way (which make the microphone crack in the recording), nice change of texture from a guitar-spare verse to a guitar \\"heroics\\" chorus.  The form is again minor to major. 3.5/5<br /><br />5. I'm Not Okay (I Promise)- is easily the second (and maybe even first) best track on the album.  The guitars are driving, there are nice interludes after the main verse, chorus, etc.., you feel \\"emo\\" in its best here.  5/5<br /><br />6.  The Ghost of You- this track gets my lowest marks for the entire album.  It is still a good track, but for me, it doesn't have the same oomph as better tracks on this album. 3/5<br /><br />7. The Jetset Life Is Gonna Kill You- nice chords and nice rhythmic feel especially at the chorus.  The driving guitars are once again a plus and Gerald Way stretches vocal limits adding just a touch of falsetto to the mix.  4/5<br /><br />8. Interlude- NO SCORE<br /><br />9. Thank You For The Venom- another top track for me from this album.  The same commentary basically for my highest scoring tracks. 4.5/5<br /><br />10.  Hang 'Em High- Nice guitar arrangements, slightly busy, but amazing. 4.5/5<br /><br />11.  It's Not A Fashion Statement, It's A Deathwish- again, another angst driven track with driving guitars, with excellent chord changes, yet in some respects it sounds too similar to better tracks on this album. Still a good track. 3.5/5<br /><br />12. Cemetery Drive- good deceptive chords, yet this track doesn't compare to HELENA or I'M NOT OKAY.  3/5<br /><br />13.  I Never Told You What I Do For A Living- a very nice ending to this album. Gerald has a nice clarity to his voice here and there are just beautifully used chords here.  Another one of my favorite tracks. 4.5/5<br /><br />Overall, the scores of the songs average out to a little bit more than 4 stars.  This is a 4 star album and I hope that young bands like MCR keep pumping out more and more innovations. This album itself is a rock masterpiece. Highly recommended. 4/5.touch of falsetto to the mix.  4/5 <br /> <br />8. Interlude- NO SCORE <br /> <br />9. Thank You For The Venom- another top track for me from this album.  The same commentary basically for my highest scoring tracks. 4.5/5 <br /> <br />10.  Hang 'Em High- Nice guitar arrangements, slightly busy, but amazing. 4.5/5 <br /> <br />11.  It's Not A Fashion Statement, It's A Deathwish- again, another angst driven track with driving guitars, with excellent chord changes, yet in some respects it sounds too similar to better tracks on this album. Still a good track. 3.5/5 <br /> <br />12. Cemetery Drive- good deceptive chords, yet this track doesn't compare to HELENA or I'M NOT OKAY.  3/5 <br /> <br />13.  I Never Told You What I Do For A Living- a very nice ending to this album. Gerald has a nice clarity to his voice here and there are just beautifully used chords here.  Another one of my favorite tracks. 4.5/5 <br /> <br />Overall, the scores of the songs average out to a little bit more than 4 stars.  This is a 4 star album and I hope that young bands like MCR keep pumping out more and more innovations. This album itself is a rock masterpiece. Highly recommended. 4/5.
B0006L16N8|5.0|With the astronomical success of their sophomore record \\"A Rush of Blood To the Head,\\" Coldplay has outdone themselves with their third release, \\"X&Y\\". <br />Chris Martin, singer, keyboardist, songwriter, married actress Gwyneth Paltrow and welcomed daughter Apple into the world in 2004. It seemed as if music was put on the backburner with his new roles as a husband and father. However, Martin and his mates wrote an amazing record which could potentially surpass the success of their previous record. <br />Opening with the powerful, \\"Square One\\", \\"X&Y\\" electrifies it's listeners with passionate, heart-felt lyrics of starting over and Martin proclaiming that everyone is the same no matter what their status might be. <br />\\"What If?\\" could be the next potential single from the record if it's not, \\"Fix You\\" which the band collectively dubbed \\"the best song they've ever written,\\" when they introduced the record live on MTV. <br />\\"What If?\\" has answered the question many ask themselves during a relationship. \\"What if I got it wrong, and no poem or song, could put right, what I got wrong, or make you feel I belong...\\" Martin sings, proclaiming a confessional for anyone involved in a relationship that is heading south. With the very catchy refrain this is a definite sing-a-long. <br />\\"Fix You,\\" is by far the greatest Coldplay song ever written. Martin's lyrics careen through the soul and make one debate what the problem is with their lives and relationships. The band considered this song as \\"Clocks Part II\\" due to the description of relationship struggles and musical similarities. Martin struggles to think about a missed chance at a perfect sitation in \\"Fix You\\" with the tear jerking line, \\"When you try your best but you don't succeed,\\" that line could relate to just about anyone who has ever struggled with taking advantage of opportunities. <br />\\"Speed Of Sound\\", the first single from \\"X&Y\\", is very reminiscent of a U2 song with it's echoing guitars and Martin's scratchy vocals.   <br />\\"Swallowed In The Sea\\" and \\"A Message\\" are the true love songs on the record, with Martin chiming in on wanting his significant other by his side. <br />Really, there are no low points to this record. The record is a rollercoaster ride of emotional movement from start to finish. From up-beat catchy riffs to the heartfelt mellowness, \\"X&Y\\" is Coldplay's first complete record, that accomplishes every goal fans need. A record that you can listen to, cover to cover, without  skipping through to the next song. <br />And, as if having 12 perfect songs wasn't enough, \\"X&Y\\" uncovers a hidden gem from the Coldplay catalog. \\"'Til Kingdom Comes,\\" a song the band wrote for Johnny Cash is a bonus track on the record. The song was written for Cash to use on his last record, which he never completed due to his death, so the band decided to put this on the record, paying homage to the musical icon. <br />\\"X&Y\\" does however lay to rest those nasty rumors of comparisons to U2 and Radiohead, with their very own introspective lyrics and unique sound. Coldplay makes a name for themselves amongst top acts. With the mercury still rising from the heating of Coldplay's popularity, \\"X&Y\\" should be up at the top of the best albums of the year, and maybe the best albums ever.

B0002VKZL6|2.0|The music of Mark Knopfler has always been most interesting for the lead guitar. More so than for almost any other musician, it has always almost seemed that he was doing a duet with his guitar, and often times the guitar tells as much of the story of the song as do the lyrics. But, sadly, that is for the most part missing from this album. Many of the songs on this album are \\"nice,\\" but (except for a few short passages) I get the sense that he is holding back with the lead guitar, and it is relegated to the supporting role of providing melody rather than the prominence of his most-loved songs. I just kept waiting for him to break out with his well-known guitar solos on so many songs, but they just did not come, and the listener is left feeling that something was missing. And without that lead guitar taking off, these are just a bunch of regular old songs without anything much special.

B0002PUHF6|4.0|This film is based loosely on a H.P.Lovecraft tale. The producer and director, both, went on to be involved in several other Lovecraft projects. Stuart Gordon directed this film, and it was put together and produced by Brian Yuzna. Yuzna became the director of the three sequels. Gordon had a reputation as an avante garde theatrical director in Chicago.<br /><br />Lovecraft created a fictitious great book-the Necronomicon-containing evil workings, horrendous spells, and \\"Dark things best left alone\\". Perhaps this influenced J.K. Rowling a bit as she created the world of Harry Potter. This film-with its outrageous gore, comedy, campness, and nudity-has become a cult favorite-on the par with ROCKY HORROR. It is shown late night in older theatres all over the country.<br /><br />Jeffrey Combs as Herbert West chewed up the scenery-and established a horror persona that has carried over to all the sequels. David Gale, an English actor, played his nemesis-Dr. Carl Hill. After being beheaded-his spirit carried on-carrying his head about like a jack-o-lantern. Bruce Abbott played the hero-Dean Cain-the idealistic med student lead down the path of hubris by West. Barbara Crampion was the girlfriend Megan Halsey-playing a lot of her scenes in the nude. Her Botticellian curves were much more memorable that her acting ability. The most shocking and often remembered scene in the film was the infamous \\"Severed Head Fellatio Party\\". It has to be seen to be believed.<br /><br />The film's plot was chaos-zombies tearing about-blood spurting like erupting fire hoses-nudity abounding-comic and darkly absurd bursts of dialogue. It becomes a campy remake of Frankenstein-ten times more intense. One critic wrote,\\" It is a very big wet chunk of gore-with a sick sense of humor-and some really gruesome sequences. In short-the perfect date movie.\\"

B00005JNSK|5.0|I must first start by stating that the original movie (though I love Gene Wilder) was completely unrepresontational of the book. It was too blatently creepy. I'm not saying I did not like the movie, it was fairly good for what it was on its own, but it was not the beloved childrens book. <br /> <br />That being said, it is impossible to compaire these two movies as movies, as this Tim Burton version is rather close to the original Dahl story. <br /> <br />Now first, the visuals in the movie are absolutely incredible. So bright and insanely detailed (just as it should be... this is a big point that the original movie was lacking, and that I personally feel only Tim Burton could do right). Every room in the factory also has an entierly different feel to it. One of the only two down-points in this film is the fact that one is left with the feeling that they have not seen enough of the factory (but it is on purpose, because after passing the \\"relatively new\\" \\"burn ward\\" in the glass elavator, one has to wonder, what other rooms could there possibly be?). And of course, there is the rediculous contrast between the generic, perfectly rectangular buildings in the \\"city\\" and Charlie's very Tim Burton-ized, crooked, run down home on the \\"outskirts\\" (all in the middle of winter, mind you). <br /> <br />Next is the soundtrack. If you like Danny Elfman you will love this movie (well, you more rather have to be a big fan of Oingo Boingo as well). It sounds as though Burton told Elfman to just go insane with the music. And that is exaclty what the music is: insane. Throughout the film is this hard hitting, neo-80's (incredibly Danny Elfman) sound that prevailes like no other aspect in this film. I warn you though, if you are not a big fan of Danny Elfman's rediculous and over the top sound, you will not enjoy this movie (I believe this story was intended to have that kind of sound, so if you like the story of the Chocolate Factory, you may like it). You have to go to this film expecting MUSIC. I was at the midnight showing, and after the Augustus Gloop song, I looked around the theater and everyone had these stone cold faces, with only the expression of \\"what in the world am I watching?\\", as I was having a rather difficult time restraining my laughter, so as not to annoy everyone else. <br /> <br />The Cast. It is perfect. There is not a single bad actor or bad choice among them. And Johnny Depp once again amazes me to no end. His character is such an incredibly original take on Willy Wonka that completely makes sense. He very childish, sarcastic (as Wonka must be), and very weak (as a person). He is most certainly not the \\"Ominous figure\\" many see him to be as after Gene Wilder's portrayal. Which both make sense to me. Wilder saw him as this mystical character with other-worldly powers (how else does he know he isn't going to find just five spoiled brats? It seems to be logical that is the only thing you could expect from a contest like that), where Depp sees him as a child (he does run a chocolate factory, and as far as the contest is concerned, he doesn't know what to expect because he doesn't understand society, or the changes society has undergone since he secluded himself, but, as a child would, he judges all of them right from the start, giving him an underly creepy feel). Once again, amazing cast. <br /> <br />And to cap it off, the story is good and solid. Yes, some of the mystery of the book is taken out, and the backstory of Wonka may or may not be liked be some. I like all of the satiric statments about society within this film, though (which I will leave you, the soon-to-be audience member, to find yourself), and some of that comes through the backstory and the lack of mystery (which is the untimate irony). <br /> <br />I stated one of two flaws earlier. The second is the Veruca Salt scene, and what the father does. I understand what Burton was trying to achieve with that, but it just did not translate to film well. Go see themovie, you will see what I mean. <br /> <br />So overall, I understand that many people are not going to like this movie as much as I did, for one reason or another. I just ask you, before you see the film, to go into it without the thoughts of the first film in your head. And don't expect an outwardly creepy and dark Tim Burton movie, because you will be dissapointed. Expect Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.

0679720200|5.0|Albert Camus' debut novel is brief, skimpy on plot, and written in the simplest and most direct manner possible, but this is as effective a piece of literature as any because of the brilliant mind behind it.  Camus was a great philisophical and literary mind, and his books were always infused with a profound concern for the desperate, desolate human condition.  The power of such a little volume as \\"The Stranger\\" lies in the very uncomfortable truths that it manages to uncover - truths which reverberate through the reader because of the spare prose that they are presented in.     'The Stranger' is deeply depressing, and for paradoxical reasons: it is depressing because we are able to identify with the protagonist, Monsieur Meursault, and empathize with his misery, even though he is barely capable of emotion and murders a man for no real reason, remaining remorseless to the end.  The story of Meursault's meaningless life and the pointless crime that inevitably leads to his downfall will leave readers distraught because Camus is not simply writing about a sick man; he perceives Meursault's emptiness and nihilism as the mindset of any man who comes to understand the indifference of the rest of the world to his plight, and in turn becomes indifferent to everything he once found pleasurable; a romantic relationship, a good meal, a social outing, a swim in the ocean, and eventually life itself.     What hope is there for Meursault in the last days before his execution?  He knows that there is no afterlife and he has no interest in reliving his experiences in his mind or pondering them, so what will he do with the little time he has left?  Will he count cracks in the walls of his cell for a few hours of the day and sleep for the rest, or will he look for something else?  \\"The Stranger\\" ends inconclusively, allowing us to ponder the question, and leaves us sick to our stomachs at the possibility that Meursault has reached a dead end (and I was literally nauseous at the end of the book).      Camus calls on all of his readers to use what imagination they have to make their lives bearable, and I think that this is what ultimately makes \\"The Stranger\\" so powerful.  It's an important book to read in our high schools as well, especially for a generation of youth that indulges itself in the vacuous entertainments of the television and music worlds that do nothing to improve their minds or characters.  It's not a morality tale, but a provoker of thought; it asks us: how close are we to being Meursault?

The audio is horrible - the effects and the music drown out the dialog, so you either have to play it so low you have to watch subtitles for the dialog, or just be blasted by the effects track. Smith's work here with his #1 Ladies Detective Agency is not about finding clever ways to solve mysteries. So if you have yet to pick up one of his stories or are wondering why so many people love these books keep that in mind while you read them. Instead of trying to solve the puzzles or sit waiting to be shocked into sitting up biting your nails, watch how Smith pulls together a dozen interesting personal tales and then weaves them together in a magical way. In `Morality...' Smith manages to slip in a few insights into how one might manage to live a proper and upstanding life. He does so by having his characters think of the old Botswana ways or the Ten Commandments and then wonder at what is wrong with modern Botswana men and women. Then he goes about with stories that link into this theme. All in all this is a very deceivingly complex book. I am in awe of his abilities as an author. This is sort of like reading a simple version of Moby Dick with all of its layers of meaning. 0425152251|2.0|After completing Sophie's World, I am left with a profound sense of dissatisfaction and the urge to do the job properly. Jostein Gaarder attempts to present a history of (let's be a little more explicit--WESTERN) philosophy through a fictitious medium surrounded by superficial plot.  <br /> <br />Unfortunately, it fails as both a work of fiction (stilted, un-engaging plot development, contrived and unoriginal twist, and underdeveloped characters) as well as a history of western philosophy (oversimplified presentation on all philosophers (even for a child), too much time spent rehashing the greeks, and an complete omission of modern philosophy with no mention whatsoever of anglo-american pragmatism, logical positivism, hermeneutics, or post-modernists, to name but a few).  <br /> <br />Where's Fichte, or Schopenhauer(!!), or Peirce, Frege, Hsserl, Marcuse, Russel, Tarski, Wittegenstein(?!!), or Feyerabend, Habermas, Derrida, and Foucault? Heidegger apparently warrants nothing but a passing mention as 'a man who was influenced by Kierkegaard and Nietzsche.'! <br /> <br />Gaarder attempts to postulate philosophical progression, then drops the ball entirely after Keirkegaard (oh but of course, he's Scandinavian). His ignorance of 20th century philosophy is inexcusable, and his skills as a novelist could use rather a lot of work as well.
B00005QK3W|4.0|Released in 2001, Driving Rain by Paul McCartney received almost unanimous approval from the critical community. They appreciated the lack of whimsy, what some might call silliness, that imbues so many other McCartney albums, and believed Paul's young band and producer gave the music a welcome bite - they gave it their blessings as the best thing Paul had done in a long while. Interestingly, the fans, the people that truly understand and support Paul's work, are almost evenly split on the matter, calling it either a masterpiece or mediocre. I've got a foot firmly in both camps.    Like many McCartney albums, Driving Rain deals primarily with love, but the tracks can easily be divided into two topics: the loss of a loved one and newfound romance. There are no outright sunny songs on this album, nor does Paul allow himself to wallow in depression: his grief for Linda is tempered by his undying optimism, and his happiness with Heather derives a melancholy from his preceding heartbreak. Had Paul put some major effort into it, this balancing act could have produced an album like few in the McCartney catalogue. But another defining characteristic of Driving Rain is its no-frills, straightforward approach; and though Paul and what would become his touring band are all excellent musicians, many of the arrangements are thin and would have benefited from more polish - especially Macca's usually golden voice.     The same goes for the lyrics, which lack much of the whimsical imagination for which Paul has become famous and too often border on trite or boring. Stylistically, however, it is perhaps his most diverse record since 1979's Back to the Egg. It has its fair share of ingenious McCartney art-pop (e.g. the gorgeous I Do); but the disc is dominated by no one genre, ranging from gritty rock (Lonely Road) and slow ballads (Your Loving Flame) to contemporary experiments (Spinning on an Axis) and Indian raga-pop (Riding to Jaipur). So saying you're almost guaranteed to love (and, by the same token, loathe) something here. David Kahn's production either has a modern edge or a modern coldness, depending on who you ask.    I loved Driving Rain when I first heard it, but I have slowly grown out of it for one reason or another. Perhaps as I have exposed myself to more of his catalogue I have come to realize that Driving Rain may be the most middle-of-the-road (pun intended) album Paul has ever produced. That said, remember who we're talking about here - middle-of-the-road McCartney is still more than listenable.

It's bland, it's not the story Dahl wrote, it serves no purpose.<br /><br />I am not a book purist, I love the third Harry Potter film more than the more faithful first two, I think LOTR is brilliant and I've read the book 5 times, but with this film the changes where un-called for and distracting, the detracted from the fun of the story.<br /><br />Now, why four stars??? Because if you cut all the Wonka flashbacks you have a near verbatim adaptation of the book, good actors, and lots of entertainment. Just gut 20 minutes of not-in-the-book footage, re-tool the last five minutes to match the book and it's near perfect.y (the ultimate sin to Dentist Dad)  <br /> <br />Now do we blast off? Do we finish the movie with the glorious shot of the elevator ascending into the upper atmosphere? No! We end with all the old folks dressed and out of bed, eating holiday dinner and living in the factory with Charlie and Wonka. Is this ending better? No! It's bland, it's not the story Dahl wrote, it serves no purpose. <br /> <br />I am not a book purist, I love the third Harry Potter film more than the more faithful first two, I think LOTR is brilliant and I've read the book 5 times, but with this film the changes where un-called for and distracting, the detracted from the fun of the story. <br /> <br />Now, why four stars??? Because if you cut all the Wonka flashbacks you have a near verbatim adaptation of the book, good actors, and lots of entertainment. 0393324818|5.0|I do not know what took me so long to read this book.  Lewis is one of the better writers and this book did not disappoint. <br /> <br />I am a huge sports fan.  One of the issues that is ALWAYS discussed is how the little teams (small market teams) are getting screwed and how they will never be able to compete with the big money teams.  At first glance, this notion makes sense.  Big market teams have the money to go after any player they want while the small market teams are stuck picking up the cheap scraps.  Every commissioner talks about how this is going to ruin the sport because the small market teams will never be able to compete. <br /> <br />This book begins to change that thought process.  It is tiring to hear Bud Selig and others talk of how all teams are doomed simply because New York spends a lot of money.  I love how Lewis explains to the reader why that does not need to be the case.  Billy Beane and others have seen how if they try and compete with  the New Yorks, LAs, etc...with the same thought process as these teams, they will be waging a losing battle.  THey will be gobbled up and lose.  And lose often.  There are many small market teams that are still of that mindset. <br /> <br />Billy Beane and his group knew that was a losing battle so they went after another way.  This book is fascinating how it tracks the evolution of a new way of thinking...and why it was such a problem to the tradition filled baseball minds.  100 years of thinking one way and that was being challenged.  How dare they?   <br /> <br />It was fascinating to read that even when Beane and the As were having success, it was easy to just ignore them or call them an aberration.  Instead of trying to figure out why it worked for Oakland...they were simply dismissed or labeled as 'lucky.'   <br /> <br />The book is a great read.  It was well reported and well done.  Though it was basically a research study...it read like a novel and kept you interested and bothered by how others were not seeing why it was working.  Kudos to Lewis and heres hoping that other small markets will take a new approach to tackling their losing battle.

The directing was marvelous, the events, scenes, fights, everything was so well coordinated and choreographed that it just felt very cohesive and coherent.  And unlike so many other attempts at making a comic book hero come to life, the spirit of the comic book has been carried onward faithfully, and very artistically.  <br /> <br />The original X-Men was the greatest comic book series going on in Marvel Comics, and was a work of art.  It was also my very favorite as a child, and watching the movie version, either I or II, really brings the whole X-Men experience back to life for me.   The X-men were a raw dose of the real substance of \\"science fiction\\" that was less respectable, and often more artistic.  And it was the artistic side that brought me back again and again.   The original comic book was drawn in an expressive fashion that really did something for me.  They did more than find better ways to say \\"Blam!\\" And the movie was true to that spirit.  <br /> <br />And as for the story and characters: The pathos of the outcast, the Macbeth-like role of the Wolverine, and the various mutants' \\"powers,\\" ancient magical powers dressed up as science; this is some of the stuff that made the X-Men so powerful an experience for any dejected 12 year-old with a quarter (like me) way back when.  And even now I think fondly of my childish fantasies of developing my native telepathic powers and joining the ranks of the X-Men, so those local boys wouldn't ever beat me up and steal my lunch money again. If I could have worked that out, I would have been able to spend alot more playing Asteroids.  <br /> <br />It was also great seeing Rebecca Romijn-Stamos without her makeup for a little while.  Definitely the most gorgeous Russian bad-gal actress I have looked upon for a while.  She really steals the show in that skimpy blue outfit.   <br /> <br />I can't wait for X-Men III to come out, and I guess it should be beginning production in a early August.  Therre are not many movies I look forward to eagerly, but if you want a little escape to a land of childhood adventure, you could hardly do better.

B000002NJS|5.0|Madonna returns with the GRAMMY award winning \\"Ray Of Light\\" and possibly her most mature album to date. Her past work has been inconsistent and patchy. Madonna has the potential to pull off some great albums and so far critically her best work up to the release of \\"Ray Of Light\\" was \\"Like A Prayer\\". Madonna has been one of the most inventive and raw artists of all time and one of the most recognisable artists of the 20th century onwards.<br /><br />For fans this is the ULTIMATE Madonna album because for years she had been billed as a 'Material Girl' and with this album she saved herself from her early 90's slump and re-invented herself into a more appealing and wholesome. This album is probably her first album free of sex, controversy and 80's pop. Now Madonna is a great artist and I really admire her work and this album is one of my favourites. The way she has matured is phenomenal.<br /><br />This album works really well for me, William Orbit is certainly an asset on this album. \\"Ray of Light\\"'s biggest hit was the Billboard Hot 100 hit \\"Frozen\\" peaking at #2, yet all tracks are as good as that, some even better.<br /><br />The album kicks off with the mellow track \\"Drowned World/Substitute For Love\\". Even though it is a vey downbeat electronic track it's chorus is very strong and the verses are incredible. \\"Swim\\" is the second song on the album and it's lyrics are very well written with a good play on words. Again the chorus and beats are a highlight. The title track \\"Ray Of Light\\" is next and again demonstrates Madonna's incredible vocal talent, this is one of the best tracks for her vocally on this album. \\"Candy Perfume Girl\\" sounds a bit like track 1 & track 5 however it's a good track nonetheless and has superbly crafted lyrics. \\"Skin\\" is the longest track on the album at 6 minutes and 22 seconds yet it's well worth the listen. Next is the beautiful track \\"Nothing Really Matters\\" which has a very bouncy chorus yet staying so mature and sophisticated. The chorus is again a highlight. \\"Sky Fits Heaven\\" is yet another track on which Madonna has again re-invented herself the sound here is more subdued and mellow during the verses.<br /><br />\\"Shanti/Ashtangi\\" is a creepy and dark track that is haunting yet beautiful at the same time. I love how the lyrics are in another language, the question I'm asking is what language?<br /><br />\\"Frozen\\" is undoubtedly the most well-known track on this album and is again to put it simply, beautiful. Lush beats provide a wonderful backdrop for Madonna's vocals. \\"The Power Of Good-Bye\\" is probably my favourite track on the album as I instantly fell in love with it upon my first listen. Addictive. \\"To Have And Not To Hold\\" has a nice ironic title and a nice sound to it as well. \\"Little Star\\" is written for Madonna's child and has lovely, cute lyrics and a superb beat. The last track is \\"Mer Girl\\" written about Madonna's experience with her mum and I like the quietly hushed sound and Madonna's tender vocals.<br /><br />At the end after listening to this superb albums you wonder howmuch further she can invent herself. Critics, fans and I have fallen in love with it, no wonder it sold 18 million copies worldwide.<br /><br />Facts About \\"Ray Of Light\\":<br /><br />Singles released:<br /><br />\\"Nothing Really Matters\\" #93 US; #7 UK (WW Sales: 0.8 mil.)<br /><br /> \\"Little Star\\" (promo only release in UK)<br /><br /> \\"The Power of Good-Bye\\" #11 US; #6 UK (WW Sales: 0.9 mil.)<br /><br /> \\"Drowned World/Substitute For Love\\" (non-US release) #10 UK (WW Sales: 0.7 mil.)<br /><br /> \\"Ray of Light\\" #5 US; #2 UK GOLD (WW Sales: 1.5 mil.)<br /><br /> \\"Frozen\\" #2 US; #1 UK GOLD (WW Sales: 2.6 mil.)<br /><br />Album Facts:<br /><br />Ray of Light (#2 US, #1 UK) (US sales: 4 mil.,Worldwide: 17 mil.)<br /><br />source:[...]The chorus is again a highlight. \\"Sky Fits Heaven\\" is yet another track on which Madonna has again re-invented herself the sound here is more subdued and mellow during the verses. <br /> <br />\\"Shanti/Ashtangi\\" is a creepy and dark track that is haunting yet beautiful at the same time. 0446677450|4.0|I began reading this book with expectations of concrete, specific financial investments and strategies for increasing my meager wealth. Dismayed, and even angered at finding none, I nonetheless continued reading - mostly because of the relationship between the author and his *rich dad* (actually a friend's father). The lessons the rich father bestowed on the author are charming, insightful and, most of all, revolultionary. <br /> <br />In the beginning, Mr. Kiyosaki's message reminded me of that Steve Martin joke: How to live like a millionaire without paying taxes. First, get a million dollars. Then, don't pay taxes. The oversimplification of what, on the surface, appears to be an obvious solution, alienated me. The author maintains that to be successful managing wealth, one needs to become EDUCATED in managing wealth. Well . . . duh. <br /> <br />However, his message is directed at a problem I didn't realize existed: the notion that *having a job and saving* will make us wealthy, or even allow us adequate retirements. I have four children. Two of them grown, one still in school, and one still in diapers. <br /> <br />The one in diapers will not receive the same advice regarding education and wealth that his brothers and sister received. <br /> <br />Although my recommendation of the content of *Rich Dad Poor Dad* is worthy of five stars, I found the quantity of redundancy and the author's amateurish sentence and paragraph structures making me wish he had spent some of his grand wealth on an editor. Minus one star for poor grammar. Otherwise, a valuable book.

It took years, but modern critics and viewers now recognize it as an epic of western filmmaking that perhaps will never be topped.  If I had to choose one movie that represented the best of the west, it is undoubtedly \\"The Searchers\\".<br /><br />John Wayne gives his most intense acting performance as the dark and vengeful Ethan Edwards, who vows to kill the Commanche raiders that murdered his beloved sister-in-law, brother, and took captive two of their daughters.  Wayne easily carries the film on his broad brooding shoulders, pursuing the Indians for over 5 years through summer and winter, ever relentless to see their chief, \\"Scar\\", dead, and his captive nieces rescued.<br /><br />Director John Ford is at the height of his creative powers in directing this western masterpiece.  He weaves so many different themes and levels of interpretation into the film, that one discovers something new with each viewing.  It would take a small treatise to bring out all the subtle details.<br /><br />Succinctly and to the point, \\"The Searchers\\" is a film that you will watch again and again, and love it each time a bit more.  It is that absolute best in western filmmaking!<br /><br />Jim Konedog Koenig

B00064X3BI|5.0|Finally, Slowhand comes to hi-resolution format. I have heard multiple CD versions from the original to the Gold Disc to the remastered, but this new SACD version just blows the rest away. <br /> <br />Slowhand has always been my favourite Clapton album over the years. Classic Clapton originals like Lay Down Sally and Wonderful Tonight define his style and songwriting capabilities and singing. His voice has an aching and tender reach on the ballads, and yet bluesy growl on the fast tracks. <br /> <br />From 461 and Slowhand, Clapton began to rely less on his guitar prowess on albums, but move towards stronger songwriting and singing to establish his albums, and Slowhand is the best example of it. And yet, his taste for covers cannot be faulted either. <br /> <br />Dusting off JJ Cale's Cocaine and William's We're With YOu All the Way shows how he can choose the right material to augment his own songs, until they blend into a seamless piece of excellent work.  <br /> <br />Ending the album with an instrumental ballad that recalls the piano coda to Layla, Slowhand remains his best and most focused work over the years. And throw in a great guitar jam in the epic Core, you get a Clapton masterwork that is as timeless now as it was commercially and critically successful during its original release almost 30 years ago. <br /> <br />Listening to the 5.1 mix by the original producer, Glyn Johns did a superb work. Although some has commented the mix sounds muddy, its actually not and its true to its original sound. Its natural and spatial mix and creative surround mixing by Johns gives this classic a new dimension that was not there before. <br /> <br />The electric solos now sound more alive and kicking and even the tender fender licks that kick off Wonderful Tonight sounds so much there and enveloping. Its the drums that has a tendency to sound muddled underneath and the strong bass levels that gives the muddy impression. BUt '70s recordings tend to be presented in such fashion and listening it over again, the surround mix is just perfect and natural. Compared to the bright but not as creative surround mix of 461, this is far superior in the end. <br /> <br />A compulsory purchase and listening for every Clapton fan. <br /> <br />

I actually enjoyed the book, and we even enjoyed the movie together. But I warn readers and potential readers: Tread cautiously. And if you meet someone claiming to LOVE Ayn Rand - run fast and don't look back. <br /> <br />It's not cool or noble to emulate Howard and Dominique to prove to the world and yourself just how important it is to only think of yourself and no one else. Living your life like this on a daily basis can cause destruction, pain, years of heartache and can damage the lives of those around you for years to come.  <br /> <br />This is what my former husband did. Woke up one morning and out of the blue, told me he didn't want to be married anymore.  What did he cite? Ultimately, Ayn's edict of selfishness. My inability to understand this caused my husband to leave me. Operating for himself and only for himself, he continued to disintegrate little by little - taking a married woman as his mistress, breaking up hers and our marriage, isolating himself from friends and family, and several years later - continuing to live a lie - all masked under Ayn's philosophy of selfishness. <br /> <br />The end of my marriage nearly killed me. If I could stop the sad reality of divorce in this country, I would. In my 31 years of existence, I've experienced nothing worse. But now I'm happy to report that I have found a partner who exhibits more selfLESSness on a daily basis than I ever thought was possible. And I've been blessed to witness the other extreme. This is how we're meant to live on earth - making the world a better place and helping those in need. I'm not saying that one's own needs aren't important- they certainly are - just not at the expense of dozens of loved ones and certainly not to appease Ms. Rand as she rots in her grave. <br /> <br />Read the book and see what I mean. Read the book to become well-versed in Rand's banter and atheist philosophies. Just don't read the book and become an advocate of selfishness. The world doesn't need any more of those.

B000001EL3|5.0|This is Kiss's fifth studio album. It was also the very first Kiss album I ever had. It is still one of my favorites. (And I usually get bored of albums quickly!) The majority of the songs here are written by Paul Stanley. Who I find to be a great writer of songs.  <br /> <br />Everything is very powerful from start to finish. This album along with Alive! are the trademark albums of the makeup years. They remind us of the good old times. Not to say everything in the non-makeup era is bad because that is not true. Anyway hears my point of view on the album. <br /> <br />1) DETROIT ROCK CITY: This song was written by Paul Stanley and Bob Ezrin (The producer) and I would have to say is my favorite. It starts you off with an intro from a radio station about a young kid who was driving on the wrong side of the road and had a head on collision with a delivery truck. After this fades out the car starts and eventually you hear that oh so addictive beat fade in from Gene's bass guitar. By the way the song is a story about the young kid who dies on the way to a concert. Unbelievably catchy chorus line. Great Ace solo. <br /> <br />2) KING OF THE NIGHT TIME WORLD: Another Paul Stanley piece. During this song he is reffering to himself as a sort of undeniable king. That everybody wants to be like or be with. Lines like, \\"I'm the king of the night time world/Come live your secret dream.\\" It's not my favorite but does appear on atleast one greatest hits compilation. <br /> <br />3) GOD OF THUNDER: I love this one it  is so mesmerizing. Lot's of neat sound effects. It was written by Paul but sung by Gene Simmons. A song about being the greatest of all gods. Commander of everything. Lines like, \\"I was born on Olympus,\\" \\"I am the lord of the wastelands,\\" and \\"I command you to kneel before the...God of Thunder!\\" A great gothic stomper. Perfect for kiss. <br /> <br />4) GREAT EXPECTATIONS: This song goes out to all of Gene Simmons' ladies. Features a chorus of some sort kids choir. \\"You watch me playing guitar, and you see what my hands can do/And you wish you were the one I was doing it to.\\" Just a taste of what to expect. It's so Gene. <br /> <br />5) FLAMING YOUTH: I never really warmed to this song. Although it is written by Gene, Paul, and Ace! Basically it is about what's plainly written in the title, childhood behavior. Sung by Paul.  <br /> <br />6) SWEET PAIN: This one is Gene Simmons all the way. With words like, \\"You'll get to love me and my sweet pain/My love will drive you insane.\\" A surprisingly delightful immature song. <br /> <br />7) SHOUT IT OUT LOUD: A great party song thats just a lot of fun. Also has a bonus of Paul Stanley and Gene Simmons in an almost duet. Just crank it up and have fun. And make sure to shout it out loud! <br /> <br />8) BETH: This song is absolutely amazing. You can hear the angst in Peter Criss' voice as he sings to his beloved wife. Powerful lyrics, \\"You say feel so empty/That our house just ain't a home/I'm always somewhere else/And your always there alone.\\" And of course the touching refrain of \\"O, Beth what can I do?\\" An out of this world love song. <br /> <br />9) DO YOU LOVE ME?: Another song by Paul Stanley. Which fits Kiss perfectly. \\"You like the concerts and studios/And all the money, honey/But...Do you love me?\\" Is it true love or just love for the money? \\"Do really love me?\\" <br /> <br />To wrap up this album, I think it is amazing. no contest top three kiss albums ever. It just brings you back to the makeup era. The crazy concerts, the raw party instincts. It's just the definitive kiss album. This is who they were. If you want the real kiss get this album.

Here we get the rundown on the League of Shadows and that stuff, and Bruce Wayne's history and condition is explained from the beginning. There are slow moments, but also many jarringly violent scenes, so it is ultimately hard to access once its over. Plus it goes on for a lot longer than any other Batman film. Arty, original, and highly impressive production-wise, this movie isn't for all tastes but it is a unique picture for those who want a new Batman and for a new vision of a superhero. The greatest superhero movie ever it is NOT, but if you can handle its brutality and nightmarish realism (basically), you may find it to be the best film of the year. B0002KVUKM|2.0|**1/2<br /><br />\\"Van Helsing\\" is a campy, tongue-in-cheek homage to the three key figures of classic movie horror - Dracula, Frankenstein's monster and the Wolf Man - and those who do them battle.  Hugh Jackman is the mysterious Van Helsing, a centuries-old monster-slayer who works sub rosa for the Catholic Church in its ongoing battle with the forces of evil.  In this tale, Van Helsing is sent off to Transylvania to destroy the famed Count Dracula, a vampire who's been rampaging through the countryside for more than four hundred years now, making life miserable for the inhabitants therein.<br /><br />Written and directed by Stephen Sommers, \\"Van Helsing\\" is a sometimes entertaining, sometimes half-baked adventure tale, beautiful to look at but largely devoid of any real suspense or excitement.  The action scenes are overwrought and redundant, filled with computer-generated special effects that are surprisingly second-rate in nature.  However, the art direction and set design do an outstanding job creating a Transylvania that plays upon our memories of those Universal classics from the 1930's.  Moreover, David Wenham serves as an effective cowardly/comic Sancho Panza-type sidekick for the more staid and conventionally heroic Van Helsing, who suffers pangs of remorse when he is forced to destroy the monsters.<br /><br />The final battle scene between Van Helsing and Dracula does drag on for a minor eternity, but the movie, overall, should satisfy rabid fans of the action film genre.  The rest of us can find intermittent entertainment gawking at the scene.

B000003TAR|4.0|Nirvana was overwhlmed by the sudden success of \\"Nevermind,\\" and the baggage that came with superstardom, so Kurt Cobain wrote punishing new songs and hooked up with noise maven Steve Albini (of 'Surfer Rosa' fame) to make this album. And from start to finish, this is a more diverse album than \\"Nevermind,\\" showing that, even though Kurt was trying to alienate his audience, he was still progressing as an artist. \\"Serve the Servants\\" features harsh commentary on his father and the ill-treatment of Courtney Love, \\"All Apologies\\" is easily one of Nirvana's finest ballads, and the noisy bursts of effected feedback that drench the ironically titled \\"Radio Friendly Unit Shifter\\" are pure genius. But parts of this album are simply too indulgent, such as the silly \\"Tourette's,\\" \\"Rape Me,\\" which angrily (and stupidly) rewrites his biggest hit and \\"Very Ape,\\" which feels more like a last-minute rumination than a full song. But this is still an excellent album, though I don't suggest this to the 'Nevermind' crowd.

B000268QB2|5.0|If I had read reviews likening Keane to Coldplay I would never have gone near this album. For me, Coldplay are a symptom of the sad state of music today - that such a boring, uninspiring non-event of a band could end up at the top of the commercial heap is out of my comprehension. <br />Luckily, Keane and this album are altogether different. For a start, in Tom Chaplin Keane have a great, versatile voice capable of projecting the songs' abundant emotions with both strength and delicacy. Although quite unique, in different places his singing reminds me of several other good voices such as Morten Harket of A-ha, particularly regarding the range, and mid/late-80s Hugh Cornwell of The Stranglers (the track Untitled I could be that very band from that era). The melodies, bridges and other changes are interesting throughout this CD, and most amazingly for an album today I don't feel the urge to skip any songs. On the contrary, even if I've just enjoyed a favourite and wouldn't mind listening again, I'll wait for the disc to wrap. While obvious influences such as an occassional 80's U2-style piano riff may be present here and there, the band and album have a distinctive sound. <br /> <br />I also like the style of writing/lyric, where the exact meaning isn't clear, leaving the listener to interpret what the song is about.  <br /> <br />To wrap up, this CD has rekindled my hopes for modern music. With a bit of luck the band will cope with success and go from strength to strength with an equally strong follow-up. <br /> <br /> <br />

B00004XMS0|4.0|I know I have already reviewed all four \\"Batman\\" movies individually, but I won't shy away from reviewing this boxed set containing all of them. I actually bought all the films in the boxed set rather than separately, but I decided to review them individually because I was too lazy to write a full review of the boxed set. Tonight, I feel like I'm able to write a thorough review of it, so here goes nothing.<br /><br />\\"Batman\\" (1989, PG-13) The first film in the series was directed by modern day cinema wizard Tim Burton. Michael Keaton takes on the role of the title character and his alter ego Bruce Wayne. In it, the Dark Knight is a vigilante hero out to thwart the criminals that plague Gotham City. The problem is, most of the citizens of Gotham think he's just as bad as the thugs he's beating up. However, their opinion changes when they get a load of the Joker (Jack Nicholson), aka former mobster Jack Napier. The Joker is out to poison Gotham City with his lethal Smilex gas, the same chemical that left him horribly disfigured in a duel with Batman. Meanwhile, Batman's alter ego, millionaire Bruce Wayne, is struggling with his secret life, which gets in the way of his blossoming relationship with beautiful photojournalist Vicki Vale (Kim Basinger), who The Joker also has his eye on. The plot may seem cluttered from a distant point of view, but all the elements mesh together perfectly and the film is excellent.<br /><br />The cast is great. Keaton is the definitive Batman (slightly better than Christian Bale). A lot of people scoffed at him being cast for the role, but their opinion changed when they saw his brilliant performance. Kim Basinger wasn't amazing, but she put in a very good performance. And Jack Nicholson was excellent as The Joker. He doesn't carry the film or steal the show in any means whatsoever, but he portrays the character to the hilt but never overdoes it. This is truly one of his best roles ever. Add to that an outstanding supporting cast that includes Robert Wuhl, Billy Dee Williams and Jack Palance, as well as stunning special effects and visuals, and the series is off to a great start. 5/5<br /><br />\\"Batman Returns\\" (1992, PG-13) Three years after the successful first venture, Tim Burtons gets behind the camera again while Michael Keaton dons the cape and tights once more in this brilliant sequel, which is every bit as good as the original. In it, Batman has to face off with not one, not two but three villians. First, there's the Penguin (Danny DeVito), aka Oswald Cobblepot, a grotesque, birdlike man abandoned by his parents as an infant, who has teamed up with crooked businessman Max Shreck (Christopher Walken). Together, they plan to get Oswald elected mayor of Gotham and drain the city of its energy supply. And then there's Catwoman (Michelle Pfeiffer), the former Selina Kyle, Shreck's secretary who he supposedly killed after finding out his plan. To make matters worse, Bruce Wayne, Batman's alter ego, and Selina have become romantically attracted to each other when they're beating the crap out of each other. This brilliantly written plot culminates in an unforgettable showdown with all four main characters.<br /><br />The cast, like the last one, is flawless. Keaton is once again amazing as Batman/Bruce Wayne. He's even better here than in the first one. Michelle Pfeiffer sizzles as Catwoman/Selina Kyle, exuding sex appeal and putting on a showstopping performance. Danny DeVito was born to play The Penguin by physical features (well, height) alone. But his performance is so convincing that he could be seven feet tall and still put on a great performance. Christopher Walken is great as always. The supporting cast includes Pat Hingle and Michael Gough, who return to their respective roles (Commisioner Gordon and faithful Wayne butler Alfred), as well as cameos by Jan Hooks, Vincent Schiavelli and Paul Reubens that give this film extra kick. 5/5<br /><br />\\"Batman Forever\\" (1995, PG-13) All good thingmust come to an end, and this film proves it. Keaton walked out of it after he was refused a larger salary, and Burton only co-produced this mess. The directing reins were handed over to veteran schlockmeister Joel Schumacher, who stripped away the first two films' gothic elements and turned Gotham City into Camp City. Val Kilmer takes on the role of Batman/Bruce Wayne, and plays the role with about as much appeal as a city sidewalk. Nicole Kidman is very pretty but a stiff love interest, Tommy Lee Jones is a terrible Two-Face and Chris O'Donnell is woefully bad as Robin. Jim Carrey plays The Riddler and carries this film on his back. He is the only good actor in this film. Though a little over the top at times, the role is tailor made for him and he is the film's saving grace. 2/5<br /><br />\\"Batman & Robin\\" (1997, PG-13) I don't even want to go into  this mess. Read my individual review. 0/5<br /><br />Should you get this boxed set? Only if you want to be able to buy all the movies in one trip and see how the films' evolution (deevolution?). Otherwise, just buy the first two and go to the movies and see \\"Batman Begins\\".s it. Keaton walked out of it after he was refused a larger salary, and Burton only co-produced this mess. The directing reins were handed over to veteran schlockmeister Joel Schumacher, who stripped away the first two films' gothic elements and turned Gotham City into Camp City. Val Kilmer takes on the role of Batman/Bruce Wayne, and plays the role with about as much appeal as a city sidewalk. Nicole Kidman is very pretty but a stiff love interest, Tommy Lee Jones is a terrible Two-Face and Chris O'Donnell is woefully bad as Robin. Jim Carrey plays The Riddler and carries this film on his back. He is the only good actor in this film. Though a little over the top at times, the role is tailor made for him and he is the film's saving grace. 2/5    \\"Batman & Robin\\" (1997, PG-13) I don't even want to go into  this mess. Read my individual review. 0/5    Should you get this boxed set? Only if you want to be able to buy all the movies in one trip and see how the films' evolution (deevolution?). Otherwise, just buy the first two and go to the movies and see \\"Batman Begins\\".

B00005JNJT|4.0|I was just a 7 year old kid when batman forever came out and it was followed by batman and robin. And the fact is that i wasnt old enough to grasp the grotesque direction the series had been steered in to by the release of those two movies. To me the Cartoonish and hi-tech action of the two movies seemed amusing along with how Batman was now being portrayed as more of a happy go lucky crime fighter rather then a \\"dark knight\\". But as i grew older and became more of a comic book fan i realised that those two movies had failed to portray the character accurately. I saw the first two baman movies \\"Batman\\" and \\"Batman Begins\\" to further see how the series had started out really well but was ending up going in a wrong direction. <br /> But this movie changes all that. Batman Begins is everything a batman movie should be. New director Christopher Nolan takes the whole experience of the movie closer to the feel of the comic books, something true fans are bound to appreciate. A darker edgier batman is portrayed by Christian Bale who is probably the best Batman yet. The movie lays emphasis on story and plot rather then stupid cartoonish antics, so if you are one of those people who just expect the action to keep flowing because you are not mature enough to appreciate the storyline then this movie is not for you. Bottom line is all hardcore fans of the comic books will not be dissapointed. There have been many dissapointed fans who have complained about the previous two batman movies, but rest assured there prayers have been answered with this masterpiece

B000002AS3|5.0|Oasis finally released their debut album \\"Definitely Maybe\\" in August of 1994, and what a triumphant debut it is.  Oasis had already been kicking around for a quite a while before this album came out--terrific early songs such as the scorching \\"Take Me\\" and the hauntingly desperate \\"Colour My Life\\" remain officially unreleased although they've been much bootlegged.  Noel Gallagher worked painstakingly to get \\"Definitely Maybe\\" just right, reportedly having the band record the whole album three times due to dissatisfaction.  Looking beyond all the hype, tabloid coverage, and so forth, \\"Definitely Maybe\\" is truly a superb and timeless album that deserved to be a smash hit, which it was.  Much has been made of the derivative nature of Oasis' music--'borrowing' the T. Rex \\"Bang A Gong\\" riff for \\"Cigarettes & Alcohol\\"; ripping off that Coca-Cola jingle for \\"Shakermaker\\"--but the thing is, this truly sounds like an album that should take the world by storm.  The production here is phenomenal--with crisp and booming drums, rich guitar tones, and Liam Gallagher's frequently sneering vocals, song after song jumps out at you and captivates with a uniquely huge and bracing sound.  Noel seems to be tapping into a variety of British influences, from the Beatles, Stones, Who, and Kinks, all the way through the likes of the Stone Roses, Happy Mondays, Spaceman 3, and My Bloody Valentine.  The music hall-flavored \\"Digsy's Diner\\" and the album-closing acoustic ballad \\"Married With Children\\" are fun and enjoyable songs that mix things up a bit.  As for the rest of the songs, each and every one is a gem.  The contemplative \\"Live Forever\\" and the passionately yearning \\"Slide Away\\" are soaring rock 'ballads'. \\"Supersonic\\" and the uptempo \\"Bring It On Down\\" are edgy rockers. \\"Up In The Sky\\" is a blissful, psychedelic-tinged feel-good song. \\"Columbia\\" is an infectious, relentlessly rocking groove-tune.  \\"Rock 'n' Roll Star\\" and \\"Cigarettes & Alcohol\\" are enthusiastic, celebratory rockers.\\"Shakermaker\\", which does bear resemblance to the Beatles instrumental \\"Flying\\", uncannily incorporates that Coca-Cola melody into a 12-bar blues format and adds a soaring bridge.  Noel's lead guitar work is terrific--although his playing isn't technically virtuosic by any means, Noel is a master of 'serving the songs' and knowing just what notes to play for maximum impact, plus having such great guitar tone doesn't hurt--just check out the extended song-ending solo on \\"Bring It On Down\\", the blazing leads on \\"Columbia\\", or the long fade on \\"Slide Away\\" for proof. Granted, there's not a whole heck of a lot of variety here in terms of arrangement--it's pretty much guitars-cranked-up-to-11 on song after song--but what a great sound.      I think most serious music listeners have a handful or so of albums that had that 'life changing' impact that marks a turning point of sorts in their lives--\\"Definitely Maybe\\" definitely had that impact on me when I first bought and played it back in March of '95, and it still sounds great all these years later.  No doubt about it, \\"Definitely Maybe\\" is a must-have album.    (P.S.  I do want to point out the Japanese CD version which slips in two more great songs--the rocking \\"Cloudburst\\" and the Noel-sung acoustic ballad \\"Sad Song\\"--while keeping the rest of the track listing intact and in the same order.  \\"Sad Song\\" can be found on the Japanese \\"Don't Go Away\\" CD single but with an unfortunate 'sudden ending' (admittedly a minor gripe), making the Japanese \\"Definitely Maybe\\" version preferrable.  \\"Cloudburst\\" can also be found on the \\"Live Forever\\" UK CD single.)
0440234743|4.0|I usually read mysteries and tend to steer clear of courtroom dramas, so I had my doubts about reading this book, but I was delightfully surprised.     \\"The Testament\\" tells of a self-made billionaire who dies and, because he despises all of his deadbeat heirs, leaves his entire eleven billion dollar estate to his illegitimate daughter, who works as a missionary ministering Christianity to a primitive tribe on the banks of the Pantenal River in Brazil. Nate O'Riley, a litigator for the law firm that represents the late billionaire (and also a recovering alcoholic and drug addict), is assigned the task of locating her and informing her of the situation. Of course, because she lives with the tribe in a feral part of the jungle, finding her will not be an easy task, and it sets O'Riley on a path to personal redemption.    Though it can be a little slow-moving at times, my advice is to bear with this story and you will not be disappointed by the resolution. It's an extremely beautiful tale of redemption, and how all the riches of the world can't compare to the wealth of eternity.
B00004LMAH|5.0|Released in February of 2000 after a bit of a hiatus and with Paul Arthurs and Paul McGuigan both gone, \\"Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants\\" finds Noel Gallagher determined to re-invent Oasis. Quite frankly, he didn't really succeed (as Noel would be the first to admit), but that doesn't mean this album is a failure. There are some mild techno/ electronica flavorings to be found, plus some gospel-like backing vocals on a few tracks, but realistically, for the most part \\"...Giants\\" wholeheartedly embraces the trademark Oasis sound. Furthermore, you can hear a lot of traces of previous Oasis songs on here--notice the choruses on \\"Who Feels Love?\\", the chord progression is a carbon copy of the chorus from \\"Hey Now!\\"; \\"Put Yer Money Where Yer Mouth Is\\" is strikingly similar to \\"(I Got) The Fever\\"; and the riff-rocker \\"I Can See A Liar\\" seems to incorporate snippets/ pieces from at least a handful of previous Oasis songs. All that said, this is still a great album. Liam Gallagher gets his first songwriting credit on an Oasis release with the amusing yet heart-tuggingly earnest and charming 3-chord power ballad \\"Little James\\". Apart from that, Noel's once again running the show, often filling in on bass as well, and he's got lots to offer. \\"Go Let It Out\\" is a great rousing anthem. The haunting and explosive \\"Gas Panic!\\" is intense and cathartic. \\"Roll It Over\\" has arrestingly dreamy verses, forceful Liam vocals, & a flawlessly-executed \\"Come Together\\"-ish guitar solo. The moody \\"Put Yer Money Where Yer Mouth Is\\" sounds a tad forced with Noel's cameo vocal appearance toward the end, but otherwise it's a great surging rocker, as is the raging \\"I Can See A Liar\\". Noel sings lead on two songs--\\"Where Did It All Go Wrong?\\" isn't a bad song, although it does sound startlingly generic for Oasis; \\"Sunday Morning Call\\" is a little rote and melodramatic, but it's still strong, and again, has an arresting dream-like atmosphere. The Eastern-flavored \\"Who Feels Love?\\" is marred by anannoying loop, but overall it's pretty great and has excellent vocal harmonies.    This Japanese version of the album adds the soaring, powerful, somewhat otherworldly-sounding anthem \\"Let's All Make Believe\\" as the final track.  \\"Let's All Make Believe\\" is also available as the b-side to the \\"Go Let It Out\\" UK CD single, as well as on a bonus disc that was included in supposedly \\"limited edition\\" pressings of the album in the US.  Ironically, \\"Let's All Make Believe\\", along with another b-side \\"One Way Road\\", sound more like an extention into exciting new territory for Oasis than most of the remaining tracks on the actual album.    I do feel that \\"Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants\\" is weaker than each of Oasis' preceeding albums, but like I said, this is still a great album, and it certainly doesn't deserve the mind-boggling negativity that it has received by many fans.
B0009MDPYM|3.0|Keanu Reeves will undoubtedly never win an Academy Award for acting. That is actually a shame, because I think he delivers some really great performances. He's not as annoyingly flashy as Tom Cruise, as oddly lovable as Tom Hanks, or as physically expressive as Brad Pitt, but Reeves plays his characters as extensions of himself (which, by the way, as an actor myself, is the only way any human being can actually play a role) and his own internalization of his emotions. Reeves' eyes tell the story, not his face. The way he might hold his head provides you insight that another actor might display on his face. <br /> <br />All that said, Reeves' portrayal of John Constantine is as unique as his character of Jack Traven (Speed) was. (While I love the first Matrix, I was sorely disappointed by the director's vision and delivery of the sequels). Reeves delivers a great performance in Constantine. <br /> <br />John Constantine has always been tortured by the gift of seeing the evil that lurks just outside of the vision of most all other humans. When it became too much for him as a teenager, he committed suicide. He was brought back 2 minutes later, empowered with the ability to return \\"halfbreed\\" demons to Hell when they overstepped their boundaries. Unfortunately, he was also damned to hell for having committed suicide. Constantine continues to protect humans from the half breed demons in an effort to save his own soul. <br /> <br />With really cool sets and a script that keeps you guessing (with the exception of the ending), Constantine delivers a moody and surreal landscape for this world and that of hell. The demons are unique but not particularly scary. The scary stuff is the Biblical references. <br /> <br />This is based on a comic from Vertigo (DC) Comics. It's a dark film and I can only suppose that the comic was equally so. <br /> <br />I think the script was very engaging and tight up until the end. The ending of the film seems to take the easy way out. Whereas we see Constantine perform a painful and drawn out <br />exorcism early on, the final exorcism - with ostensibly a far more powerful demon - takes place relatively quickly and easily. <br /> <br />I love Tilda Swinton (wonderful as usual) as the angel Gabriel and Peter Stormare as Lucifer (though his performance was not so much evil as it was weirdly silly). Rachel Weitz was really interesting as the female lead. She made me completely forget her forgettable performance in The Mummy. <br /> <br />I also particularly loved the \\"move ins\\" to Weitz's character that Reeves does on several occasions. Watch the film and you'll see what i'm talking about. <br /> <br />This is not your standard fare - but it is not a rip off of The Exorcist or any other film (though it may share some similarity with Prophecy). Far more engaging than the Order or any other film of that nature, Constantine is leaps and bounds above those other films. It is due to a decent director, but really good performances by Reeves, Weitz and Swinton and an awesome set designer and cinematographer. <br /> <br />May not be everyone's cup of tea - but if you give it a chance you'll like it.

True, \\"Cloudburst\\" is also on the \\"Live Forever\\" UK CD single; however, the version of \\"Sad Song\\" on the Japanese CD single of \\"Don't Go Away\\", although otherwise identical, has an unfortunate 'sudden ending'--the version here has a more proper and fitting ending making it preferrable.    I think most serious music listeners have a handful or so of albums that had that 'life changing' impact that marks a turning point of sorts in their lives--\\"Definitely Maybe\\" definitely had that impact on me when I first bought and played it back in March of '95, and it still sounds great all these years later. B0000028RR|5.0|I've noticed some reviewers here critiquing Rage's music and particularly their message, simply because it's \\"hypocritical\\". I'd impart these words from Tom Morello (the guitarist of RATM): <br /> <br />\\"A lot of labels contacted us, and lots of them just didn't seem to understand what we wanted to do. They kept talking about the message of the music as a gimmick. They were interested in us just because there was a buzz... They saw us as the latest local rock band to be hyped. But Epic agreed to everything we asked--and they've followed through... we never saw a conflict as long as we maintained creative control. When you live in a capitalistic society, the currency of the dissemination of information goes through capitalistic channels. Would Noam Chomsky object to his works being sold at Barnes & Noble? No, because that's where people buy their books. We're not interested in preaching to just the converted. It's great to play abandoned squats run by anarchists, but it's also great to be able to reach people with a revolutionary message, people from Granada Hills to Stuttgart.\\" <br /> <br />This band opened up the door for every other rap/rock ripoff, but actually had a message rather than self-indulgently nihilistic ranting (Korn) or adolescent posturing (Limp Bizkit). Highly recommended album, one of the best debuts in history.
B00004R960|5.0|Released in February of 2000 after a bit of a hiatus and with Paul Arthurs and Paul McGuigan both gone, \\"Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants\\" finds Noel Gallagher determined to re-invent Oasis. Quite frankly, he didn't really succeed (as Noel would be the first to admit), but that doesn't mean this album is a failure. There are some mild techno/ electronica flavorings to be found, plus some gospel-like backing vocals on a few tracks, but realistically, for the most part \\"...Giants\\" wholeheartedly embraces the trademark Oasis sound. Furthermore, you can hear a lot of traces of previous Oasis songs on here--notice the choruses on \\"Who Feels Love?\\", the chord progression is a carbon copy of the chorus from \\"Hey Now!\\"; \\"Put Yer Money Where Yer Mouth Is\\" is strikingly similar to \\"(I Got) The Fever\\"; and the riff-rocker \\"I Can See A Liar\\" seems to incorporate snippets/ pieces from at least a handful of previous Oasis songs. All that said, this is still a great album. Liam Gallagher gets his first songwriting credit on an Oasis release with the amusing yet heart-tuggingly earnest and charming 3-chord power ballad \\"Little James\\". Apart from that, Noel's once again running the show, often filling in on bass as well, and he's got lots to offer. \\"Go Let It Out\\" is a great rousing anthem. The haunting and explosive \\"Gas Panic!\\" is intense and cathartic. The album-closer \\"Roll It Over\\" has arrestingly dreamy verses, forceful Liam vocals, & a flawlessly-executed \\"Come Together\\"-ish guitar solo. The moody \\"Put Yer Money Where Yer Mouth Is\\" sounds a tad forced with Noel's cameo vocal appearance toward the end, but otherwise it's a great surging rocker, as is the raging \\"I Can See A Liar\\". It's worth mentioning that 2 of the b-sides from the \\"...Giants\\" era--\\"Let's All Make Believe\\" and \\"One Way Road\\"--sound more like an extention into exciting new territory for Oasis than most of the tracks on the actual album; perhaps Noel simply felt these two tracks didn't fit in on here, hence their b-side status. One wonders this even more since \\"Let's All Make Believe\\" was on a bonus disc that was included in supposedly \\"limited edition\\" pressings of the album. <br /> <br />I do feel that \\"Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants\\" is weaker than each of Oasis' preceeding albums, but like I said, this is still a great album, and it certainly doesn't deserve the mind-boggling negativity that it has received by many fans.  <br /> <br />(P.S.  Don't let the fact that \\"Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants\\" was released in this \\"clean version\\" give you the wrong idea--the only swearing on the album is provided by samples from the movie \\"Message To Love--The Isle Of Wight Festival\\" on the otherwise instrumental opening track \\"F***in' In The Bushes\\".)
B0006HXXBA|5.0|Best Thrash Album I have heard since South of Heaven !!!!!!
B000002C25|5.0|Released in August of 1997, Oasis' 3rd album \\"Be Here Now\\" has been much maligned over the years, not just by critics and fans, but by Noel Gallagher himself, which is a real shame because this is actually a great album that finds Oasis embracing their strengths wholeheartedly.  One highly noticeable difference with \\"Be Here Now\\" is that Oasis dropped that late '60s-style reverb-heavy sound that's so prominent on tracks like \\"Don't Look Back In Anger\\".  Oasis' huge sound had already been in full force on \\"Definitely Maybe\\" and to a lesser extent \\"(What's The Story) Morning Glory?\\", but Noel wanted to take this a step further yet--the clear goal with \\"Be Here Now\\" was to make a huge, sweeping, epic rock & roll album, and regardless of what Noel may say, they succeeded beyond all belief.  Noel wrote all the songs on \\"Be Here Now\\"; he has confessed that certain songs here had been written prior to the first album \\"Definitely Maybe, but frankly, that's just a further testament to the mass quantity of great songs he had at his disposal in his songbook.  Seriously, Noel Gallagher was 27 years old when \\"Definitely Maybe\\" came out in August of 1994, and it's an easy guess that he'd been doing plenty of songwriting before that time, so it makes sense he had a lot of material at hand considering his level of songwriting talent.  Song after song on \\"Be Here Now\\" has ultra-catchy hooks, and the album's extremely dense sound gives the album an all-encompassing feel, not unlike George Harrison's \\"All Things Must Pass\\", and this sound really works wonders here. Don't get the wrong idea that the huge sound of \\"Be Here Now\\" is indicative of it being music to knuckleheadedly chant along to in big arenas; think more along the lines of \\"Hey Jude\\"--the anthemic feel is mostly genuine, and there really is depth here. I want to point out that the lyrics here are actually far more sincere and emotional than a lot of people would lead you to believe--it's not just a bunch of obvious hippy-dippy rhyming of the kind that John Power from Cast specialized in, just to make a comparison. Oasis don't rush through things here, and that's another positive aspect--most of the songs are fittingly taken at that 'laidback Oasis tempo', and the album's pacing is masterful, using extended intros and outtros to sort of ease you along.  Apart from Noel's excellent feature on \\"Magic Pie\\", it's Liam Gallagher on lead vocals for all of the songs, and his rough-around-the-edges vocals are superb--always convicing and carrying a great deal of emotional weight.  To name a handful of the terrific songs here, there the anthemic \\"D'You Know What I Mean?\\"; the rip-roaring high-speed rocker \\"My Big Mouth\\"; the wistful \\"Magic Pie\\"; the cautionary, Allman Brothers-ish, roadhouse blues-flavored \\"Fade In-Out\\"; and the rousing, uplifting rocker \\"It's Getting Better (Man!!)\\".  I'm not going to say that the album NEVER goes at all overboard--I won't argue that it was really necessary to include a reprise of \\"All Around The World\\" when the song itself is already over 9 minutes long, and the jokey, out-of-place tacked-on ending of \\"Magic Pie\\" sounds foolish.  \\"Stand By Me\\" does have a little bridge section that very briefly pushes the song into melodramatic territory, but otherwise it's a wonderfully bittersweet power ballad with a singalong chorus.  \\"All Around The World\\" does have some admittedly hokey lyrics, but the enormous build-up really gets under your skin.  The title track and the uptempo \\"I Hope, I Think, I Know\\" are a lot of fun as well, and \\"Don't Go Away\\" is a lovely tender ballad with a refreshingly stripped-down coda.  Regardless of how derivative Oasis may be, they really did hit upon a great distinctive signature sound which is heard in all of its glory on \\"Be Here Now\\", a genuine '90s masterpiece.

1591396190|4.0|I enjoyed this book.  Good examples and easy to follow.
B0006L16N8|5.0|I used to hate this band, but when a friend give me this album, I change immediately my opinion. This is great album. All songs have a different particularity. When Coldplay become a great band...
B0006L16N8|5.0|This is not a quick listen. It's not the kind of CD you bop to as soon as you pop into the player. This, like any other Coldplay CD, is deep, hardcore stuff and you have to give it a shot. Once you do, like a week later, I swear it's addictive. I cannot get it out of my car. My husband is losing his mind at this point. It's brilliant. My favorite tracks, \\"Fix you,\\" \\"A Message,\\" or as I call it, \\" My Song is Love,\\" \\"The Hardest Part,\\" \\"Swallowed in the Sea,\\" and ofcourse the hidden track, \\"Till Kingdom Come.\\"
