Speed of Sound sounds very very similar to Clocks from their last album. I passed on this one. <br />Too bad...With Tori Amos putting out bland cds too lately, makes me think getting married and having kids turns great song writers into boring saps with nothing to sing/play for so they formulate their songs instead of them just flowing out due to creativity and emotion.
B000058983|5.0|ME GUSTA MUCHO ESTE DISCO.MUY BONITAS MELODIAS ,MUY BUENA MUSICA E INTERESANTES ARREGLOS.ESCUCHARLO CASI 40 AOS DESPUES DE CREADO ES UNA GRAN EXPERIENCIA.DEFINITIVAMENTE ES UN EXCELENTE TRABAJO DE ARTHUR LEE Y EN EL SE DEMUESTRA QUE EN ESA EPOCA NO ERA UN MUSICO MAS. <br />SIN EMBARGO COMPARARLO CON LA BELLEZA DE SARGENT PEPPER , ME PARECE QUE NO TIENE CABIDA.AMBOS SON TRABAJOS MAGNIFICOS PERO MUY DIFERENTES.LA ORQUESTACION ,ARREGLOS Y ESTRUCTURA DE SARGENT PEPPER NO TIENE COMPARACION CON NINGUN OTRO DISCO CREADO HASTA HOY DIA.DECIR QUE ES UNO DE LOS MEJORES 10 DISCOS DE LA HISTORIA DEL ROCK O AUN MAS ASEGURAR QUE ES EL MEJOR DISCO DE ROCK ES EXAGERAR Y ES TAMBIEN PONER EN LAS ALTURAS UN TRABAJO MUY BUENO QUE NO TIENE NECESIDAD DE COMPARARSE CON OTRO PARA ESTABLECER SU BELLEZA.SE LO RECOMIENDO ,PERO ESCUCHELO POR LO QUE EL SOLO VALE
0894803123|3.0|There are only two rules with using this book \\"Rule #1 You don't have to be a pro to make incredibly delicious ice cream.\\" and \\"Rule #2 There's no such thing as an unredeemingly bad batch of homemade ice cream.\\" You can always fix it if something happens or else you have just created the next NEW flavor. B001RIY4WE|5.0|The special features expand the story line, and were frequently drawn upon in the TV show, \\"The Sarah Connor Chronicles.\\" The T-1000 certainly launched the era of computer animation which was soon to come.
B0006L16N8|5.0|I've been a Coldplay fan since A Rush of Blood to the head three years ago in 2002. That album changed my life. I listened to it solidly for the whole of those three years. I think it may have left my stereo three-CD changer a total of 2 times in the entirety of my ownership. Yes, I purchased Parachutes as well, and love it too, but A Rush of Blood to the Head was the love of my musical life.  <br /> <br />So, it goes without saying that when Coldplay's 18-months-in-the-making, most-anticipated, the album-of-albums X&Y came out, I was expecting to have my brain explode, my eyes fall out of my head and other such gruesome sensations one might experience during listening to an awe-inspiring album. (At least for me...) <br /> <br />Well, I was severely disappointed.  <br /> <br />The only songs that really stood out upon first listen were, oddly enough, we the first and last tracks: (unless you count the bonus track of \\"Kingdom Come\\" as the last track) the spacey, tempo-changing opener of \\"Square One\\" and the sliding, guitar drenched, angry social commentary of \\"Twisted Logic\\".  <br /> <br />But, after maybe... five listens, I came to really enjoy and appreciate this album. And with each listen, it just keeps getting better. Warning: this album is a grower.  <br /> <br />I was pretty stupid to think that this new album could completely replace A Rush of Blood to the Head and it's importance to me in one fell swoop. But, now, after a month of listening, I think it just may fill the role. <br /> <br />The layering and instrumentation in this album is a show of true musicianship. Everything, every part has a purpose and is integrated into the piece of music seamlessly, until all the tracks on the album almost come alive with their richness. Some people maybe through off by the consistent density of this album, but others may embrace it, basking in the warm glow of musical genius. Not a note is misplaced in any song. Some people may point to this as being a flaw, as it erases human frailty from song making, but I find it as simple craftsmanship. So what if I can't hear the peddle-workings like you can in \\"Politik\\" (The crashing, epic opener of the last album)? I was never aware that peddle-workings were imperative in order to make a good album.  <br /> <br />But I digress. A song-by-song review by yours truly: <br /> <br />The opener of \\"X&Y\\", \\"Square One\\", is a much different introduction into this new album than \\"Politik\\", an opener whose very introduction was enough to blow anyone off their seats, crashing and falling like a tidal wave. \\"Square One\\", however starts out much more quietly, with a simple guitar, shimmering through some spacey synths until Martin's haunting tenor breaks through, almost uncertainly, with \\"You're in control, is there anyway you want to go?/ You're in control is there anything you want to know?/ The  future's for discovering/ The space in which we travel in\\". Cueing Will Champion, Coldplay's drummer, to come in with a staccato cymbal and simply *cool* drum riff before the song explodes into guitar and bass, Chris' voice echoing with lines like \\"From the top of the first page/ to the end of the last day\\" and \\"I need a compass, draw me a map/ I'm on the top I can't get back\\". The entire song is littered with extra little sound affects, a galloping drum affect and some amazing backing vocals that you may miss if you're not careful. The song comes to a grinding halt with the synths fading out around you, the galloping growing farther off and a soft, acoustic guitar hailing in Chris with \\"You wonder if your chance will ever come/ Or if you're stuck in square one\\". <br /> <br />After such a cathartic rocker about universal humanity and emotional inertia, the band throws you for a loop with the heart-broken ballad of \\"What If\\", starting off with Chris and his piano singing \\"What if there was no light? / Nothing wrong, nothing right?\\". The song's lyrics of insecurity and almost paranoia may throw off some, but doubts are quickly put to rest by Martin's broken voice and simple piano. Nothing obtuse. Nothing pretentious. Nothing Chicago *wink*. But then, that's what we love about this band isn't it? The song flows into a chorus with the band at full swing, Jonny, lead guitarist, provides a shiny guitar part that proves perfect accompaniment to Chris' \\"Ooo's\\" in the higher register. The band continues with full accompaniment for the rest of the song, until the wheels fall off the wagon and they go hurtling into an almost raucous crescendo that falls to silence, leaving the listener quite exhausted. But that's a good thing. ;) <br /> <br />The band leaves the piano behind for yet another song, and one of my personal favorites, \\"White Shadows\\". From first note, you know that this is not going to be any *normal* Coldplay song. The song is set over a syncopated rhythm, the drum, guitar and bass parts all seemingly entirely different, but working too well together in order for anyone with a working set of ears NOT to be impressed. Chris provides his usual pristine vocals, belting a chorus of \\"Maybe you'll get what you wanted/ Maybe you'll stumble upon it\\" upon a backdrop of some very impressive backing vocals. The song ends on nothing but some stadium synths/organs and Chris singing out, \\"Swim out in a sea of faces/ Tide of the human races/ An answer now is what I need/ See it in the new sun rising/ See it break on your horizon/ Come on love/ Stay with me\\" that leaves chills up your spine. <br /> <br />And just when you think Coldplay has out-done themselves, they travel on to \\"Fix You\\", recently being declared as Coldplay's greatest, and also, as openly stated by the band, one of their favorites they have ever written. Opening on some churchy organs, Chris comes in with \\"You get what you want, but not what you need\\". During the opening verses, other sounds join in, such as an extra organ sound, some simple strokes on a piano, some bass and a quiet acoustic guitar. Everything is going quite nicely until Jonny breaks in with a soaring guitar and Will with a building cymbal, until the drummer makes the song absolutely take flight by crashing into a part that sounds too complicated to be possible for two hands and feet (but apparently it is, upon seeing live performances). The band, after lapsing into mental stalling at the sheer beauty of what they have just created (or at least that would be what would happen to me) come in, all four members harmonizing perfectly over lines like \\"Tears stream down your face/ When you lose something you can't replace\\" and \\"Tears stream down your face/ And I...\\" until all goes quiet and we descend back to earth with Chris and piano singing \\"Lights will guide you home...\\"  <br /> <br />And, after having survived that little number, the band jumps in with guns blazing as the first, echo-y guitar notes are delivered through a fog of synths, announcing \\"Talk\\". The riff, lifted from Krafwerk's \\"Computer Love\\", is what makes this song so good. It's almost like you can't get enough of it. Chris carries us through it all with \\"You can climb a ladder up to the sun/ or write a song nobody has sung\\". The song quiets down, leaving us with synths and Will playing a little jig on his hit-hats before adding in the bass and Chris' piano until giving way to a fast, sheer genius guitar part, until an impatient crash on Will's drums announces a heavy, sawing guitar, bringing Chris back in with the chorus. The song ends with what sounds like a plane landing, but strangely fits with what the listener may feel like after listening to this gem.  <br /> <br />After this, the band makes the listener sit up in their seats when a chorus of strings comes in and Chris wasting no time coming in with \\"Trying hard to speak/ And fighting with my weak hand\\" as the title track \\"X&Y\\" starts up. After Chris gives some quiet chords upon his piano, deep bass drums come in as well as some serious guitar, melting into growing violins. The chorus givesthe illusion of floating or flying, which is quite amazing considering the actual chorus is \\"You and me are floating on a tidal wave\\". These words glide among a bright guitar part until giving way to a guitar solo that leaves you salivating. Amongst \\"ooo's\\" from Chris, the song comes to a short-lived end, a symphony of strings carrying you over to the next tack.  <br /> <br />\\"Speed of Sound\\", Coldplay's newest single, may seem like a rehashing of the \\"Clocks\\" formula to some people, but to me, it is the formula and only the formal. The song opens with a stark, hypnotizing piano riff floating amongst some synths, before Will's new-found love of bass drums kicks in to allow the first verse of \\"How long before I get in?/ Before it starts? Before I begin?\\", followed by a soaring reintroduction of the piano among a grinding guitar, the next verse being followed with guitar and bass, until the chorus breaks into Will's bass drums and then rockets up and then comes hurtling back down to the piano. The last line, held out blood-vessel-bursting-ly long by Martin, leaves the listener's bones liquefied, twitching for the next song as a static-y synths leads you on to track number 8. <br /> <br />\\"A Message\\" opens with a strumming of an acoustic guitar and \\"My song is love/ Love to the loveless shown\\". If you thought that actually saying the word \\"love\\" in a song was musically taboo in a love song and would automatically cause you to be laughed at, think again. Martin manages to make believers out of all of us once again by his simple sincerity and straightforwardness of this song. The first verse melts into the chorus when a second guitar and drums join Chris in \\"I'm not going to take it back/ I'm not going to say I don't mean that\\". The second verse comes in with an added electric guitar part that shifts like a wandering moth from speaker to speaker that makes for quite a cool effect. The song breaks for a guitar solo, Chris coming back in and causing the rest of the band to drop out with his heartfelt \\"And I love you please come home\\" until finally ending with a few strums of the guitar and some chords on the piano and an \\"And I've got to get that message home\\". <br /> <br />The guys lurch you out of ballad-dom again as \\"Low\\" comes at you, guitar soaring, bass rumbling and drums crashing. It all falls to Chris' feet as he sings \\"You see the world in black and white/ No color, no light\\" amongst bass and a truly cool guitar part that is nearly left unheard it is so ambient. The chorus comes through though with the same speediness as the intro with, \\"All you ever wanted to be/ Living in perfect symmetry\\". One thing that might be most distinctive about this song to most listeners is the \\"spoon\\" part provided by Mr. Champion. The \\"spoons\\" turn out to be wine glasses and, after a few listens, one cannot imagine the song without them. Martin proves his mastery of his falsetto and his superiority of being able to slide up and down the scale as easily as he were blinking, with the line \\"You should try\\". But just when you think this song is done surprising you, the band lurches into a key-change that would be the demise to most other songs, but Coldplay holds up once again, sawing away at their guitars as Chris \\"Oooh\\"s and \\"'Cause I feel low\\"s and even provides a 80s hair band salute to the falsetto screech. but instead of the listener wanting to set their stereo on fire, it simply compels them to fashion a closet altar to this man.  <br /> <br />The band morphs back into mellowness as \\"The Hardest Part\\" is introduced through a bouncy guitar and cheery piano and Chris singing \\"And the hardest part was letting go/ Not taking part\\". This song is one of the bumps in an otherwise spotless album. The lyrics are a bit too sugary for my tastes, but it does grow on you after awhile. The guitar slides in with new parts throughout the song that do keep it interesting, but I often find myself pressing \\"Skip\\" when this song moves up. Although, it does have a good ending, a catchy guitar and full band accompaniment fading into... <br /> <br />\\"Swallowed in the Sea\\". This song opens with only Chris \\"You cut me down a tree/ And brought it back to me\\". The melody is really quite addicting and you can't help but singing along on only your second listen. The guitar gives a long, winging note, opening up for an acoustic, bass and drums. The chorus is set upon a really great guitar part and the refrain is carried on the band's \\"Ooo\\"s and \\"Ahh\\"s. The last few lines of this song may have to screaming until you're blue in the face with the passion that Chris sings \\"Oh, what good is it to live/ With nothing left to give? / Forget but not forgive/ Not loving all you see?\\" The song halts as Chris leaves us with \\"You belong with me/ Not swallowed in the sea\\" as he provides some chords on the piano. <br /> <br />And then, upon a bed of strings, synths and ambient guitar, Chris is carried singing \\"Sunlight opened up my eyes/ To see for the first time\\" to pull you into the closer \\"Twisted Logic\\". The band comes in with some slow-moving piano, guitar, bass and cymbals until backing off to allow Chris to sing \\"Hundreds of years in the future/ There could be computers/ Looking for life on earth\\" while Jonny provides spouts of sound from his guitar that rather sound like he's hitting it with a hammer, only adding to the dark color of this song. The whole band climbs in again, providing a teaser for what's to come as Chris shouts, \\"You'll go backwards, but then/ You'll go forwards again\\". Jonny provides us with a nice riff until we are immersed back into the murky social commentary of track 12. And finally, on a sea of winging guitars and an impossibly long note on Martin's part, the song inspires the listener to successfully punch something before all the groaning of the guitars is literally SWALLOWED up by some unseen force and you are left with 30 seconds of recovery time before the next song starts. <br /> <br />\\"Kingdom Come\\", the album's not-so-hidden hidden track, proves to be an enjoyable bonus, but can't really compare to the others on the album. The guitar part and Chris' lyrics of \\"Still my heart and hold my tongue\\" do make for a good listen. The addition of the piano and harmonica are nice touches and the song ends on a beautiful note of \\"Just say you'll wait, you'll wait for me\\". <br /> <br />In conclusion: an excellent album that only needs some time to grow.  <br /> <br />And on another note, this album is at it's best when playing over headphones or on \\"Max\\" on your stereo. There's really no other way to listen to it.  <br /> <br />~panda

B0000ACY0Y|5.0|As a Gene Clark fan from the Byrds period, the \\"Gene Clark and the Gosdins\\" album failed to live up to my expectations at the time: I missed the jangly 12 string Rickenbacker and the more rock driven sensibility behind the classic \\"Feel a Whole Lot Better.\\" I found it way too demanding then to reappraise the artist within a solo context and turned my listening attention instead toward \\"Younger than Yesterday.\\"<br /><br />By 1972 I was ready to try again when I purchased the \\"Gene Clark Collector Series: Early L.A. Sessions.\\" I was feeling nostalgic for the era, a feeling exacerbated by the release of Lenny Kaye's \\"Nuggets.\\" Still rather put off by the laid back country material, I discovered vestiges of that brooding poetic genius in songs such as \\"The Same One\\" and \\"I Found You.\\" That record stayed in my collection until, by 1991, I bought the \\"Echoes\\" CD. The acoustic version of \\"So You Say You Lost Your Baby\\" really impressed me. This, along with the studio version of the tune, with its awesome string arrangement by Leon Russell, enhanced my burgeoning reaffirmation of the man, his music and legacy.<br /><br />  Finally,  I happened to come across a copy of  \\"No Other\\" listed as a reissue of his long lost masterpiece. Upon first hearing the record, I felt a sense of closure in such songs as \\"Strength of Strings\\" and \\"No Other.\\" What he alluded to in his scatter blot imagery of \\"So You Say You Lost Your Baby,\\" a musical tale told in a little over two minutes, now seemed reconfigured into a definitive musical statement.<br /><br />  The eight songs for me represent a kind of interlocking tone poem. Each song, like the \\"notes that roll on winds/with swirling wings,\\" segues into the next as naturally as our moods change according to circumstance. Each song is distinct, a world unto itself, yet finds itself somehow linked to the others by the finest of threads. From \\"Life's Greatest Fool\\" to \\"Lady of the North\\" Clark brings a deceptively simple yet elegant humanity into the emotional texture of his work. He sings of life's extremes, fraught with anger and disappointment as \\"Some Misunderstanding,\\" the sorrowful polarities of relationship in \\"Silver Phial,\\" the thoughtful paradoxes of \\"The True One,\\" and the complex unity that only the \\"Silver Raven\\" seems to know.<br /><br />  I begin to understand now why \\"No Other\\" is highly regarded. Gene Clark is a significant musical poet laureate of our generation; the quintessential Byrd. Like the archetypal cowboy balladeer of old, what appears unassuming or naive, is redeemed by his unschooled common sense, authenticity and genuine effort. Appreciation for the artistic achievement on this album will only increase, I suspect, through time. I'm sorry I have only these posthumous words to share.onal texture of his work. He sings of life's extremes, fraught with anger and disappointment as \\"Some Misunderstanding,\\" the sorrowful polarities of relationship in \\"Silver Phial,\\" the thoughtful paradoxes of \\"The True One,\\" and the complex unity that only the \\"Silver Raven\\" seems to know.            I begin to understand now why \\"No Other\\" is highly regarded. Gene Clark is a significant musical poet laureate of our generation; the quintessential Byrd. Like the archetypal cowboy balladeer of old, what appears unassuming or naive, is redeemed by his unschooled common sense, authenticity and genuine effort. Appreciation for the artistic achievement on this album will only increase, I suspect, through time. I'm sorry I have only these posthumous words to share.

B000002J1S|5.0|In the world of progressive rock, few pieces of music stand out so far ahead as the Lamb and Selling England by Genesis.  But, there are other really great works out there, and these have not been mentioned.  Allow me to suggest listening to the first three Soft Machine albums (1, 2 and Third).  Next try listening to the late romantic composer, Gustav Mahler, esp. his symphonies no. 2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10 as well as his Lieder.  Few composers can pack as much emotion as him. Stravinsky, often called the father of modern classical music, is a very great composer and I think you would adore his Rite of Spring, Petrushka and Firebird.  Schubert is very dear to my heart - listen to his sym. no. 9 and his song cycle, Winterreise.  Back to rock music, I have always adored ELP (first 7 releases), Yes (almost all), early Rush, Happy the Man, Eno, Terry Riley, Gentle Giant (almost all), and numerous Canterbury rock bands.  After listening to as much music as I have, you realize though that the finest music ever written is from Bach and Handel, but the world of music would be missing a great deal without Genesis.

B000A6T1KE|2.0|Until this movie came along, the constant pattern had been: even-numbered Trek films good, odd-numbered Trek films mediocre or bad. <br /> <br />Alas, this even-numbered (10) Trek film is decidedly mediocre.  Contrary to what another reviewer wrote, I don't think the problem was a director who had no knowledge or love of Trek.  Nicholas Meyer had neither when he was hired and he did just fine. <br /> <br />The problem is that Baird isn't that good a director.  Or, rather, he's an \\"action\\" director, meaning that the focus of what he does tends to be action and not, say, characters or story.  Nemesis shows this clearly, as we are treated to a silly chase that doesn't advance the story one bit, with Picard gleefully speeding recklessly across the terrain. <br /> <br />It's also trying too hard to be Star Trek II (but then, aren't they all?).  Picard is given a suitable villain, and themes are woven so that the Picard/Shinzon conflict can explore them.  The difference is, Shinzon ultimately doesn't work because his origin is so contrived (and unnecessary), and the themes are touched on and abandoned.  Trek II, on the other hand, had a villain who was anything but contrived, and the themes were at the heart of the story, driving it, instead of just being along for the ride. <br /> <br />Finally, there's a needless death -- I won't say who, but it's pointless, and then immediately undermined.   <br /> <br />Not all is bad.  Visually it's very well done, with some incredible effects, and there are some nice moments.  The cast, for the most part, falls into its comfort zone.  There are moments at the wedding that are downright hilarous.  It's not boring (Trek I), or silly and pointless (Insurrection), or completely incoherent (Trek V).  And I'll grab the SCE for the deleted scenes, and the text commentary (which is always brilliant). <br /> <br />Sadly this looks to be it for TNG movies.  Closer to a whimper than a bang.
B00004TH6O|4.0|Take it as a sign of things to come - upon Rated R's release, Queens of the Stone Age rapidly seemed to be ascending the throne to hard rock royalty, and the album was one of Rolling Stone's Top 10 Albums of the Year.  With the benefit of hind sight after two more QOTSA releases, Rated R seems fairly juvenile - the songs here don't have the jolting intensity of the best songs even from Lullabies to Paralyze, and they certainly never approach the monster slyness and exhileration of Songs For The Deaf.  Even the ambitions are smaller here - songs like \\"Leg of Lamb\\" and \\"Monster In The Parasol\\" rock only intermittently, \\"Feel Good Hit of the Summer\\" is a jolt, but a joking one, and the 8-minute \\"I Think I Lost My Headache\\" has moments of rock greatness, but feels quieter than everything on the next two records, preferring slow builds.  The moments that work best on this record are the atmospheric ones - \\"Headache,\\" \\"In The Fade,\\" or \\"Better Living Through Chemistry,\\" which seems to have a creepy, inactive minute midway through.  None of this makes the album bad, but it does make it, at times, feel like a wholly different group than the one that would make Songs For The Deaf.  Despite a generally solid collection of songs, I'm happy they traded atmosphere for claws.

B00008PX8P|5.0|Led Zeppelin (2003.), the Led Zeppelin double DVD live release<br /><br />Led Zeppelin, after the Beatles, are the biggest selling album band of all time, clocking in at well over 200 million sales over the last 35 years since the release of their self titled debut album. However, on the flipside, Led Zeppelin were a very, very camera shy band, who disliked giving interviews, appearing commercially or letting their concerts be filmed. As a direct result, very few live documents exist of Led Zeppelin concerts and for many years, give or take the 1976 'The Song Remains The Same' release, legions of fans just had the studio albums available to them. However, this all changed in 2003 with the release of the 'How The West Was Won' 3 CD live set and this awesome double DVD 'Led Zeppelin' live offering.<br /><br />This DVD, after numerous reviews since its release 2 years ago is not averaging 5 stars on amazon.com for nothing. This is what Led Zep fans have waited for, and this double DVD is a seriously great experience. What makes the DVD even better is that it captures the band live throughout its career. Therefore, we get a capture of the early years, when the revolutionary hard-rock blues band were taking the world by storm, on the first DVD. Then, there is the second DVD which has live offerings from concerts through the 1970's, right up until 1979, the year before the tragic death of John Bonham, which ultimately split the band. Basically you see everything, including Plant's earlier to later stirring performances on the vocals and Jimmy Page's whirlwind, perfected guitar playing. The sound quality is amazing throughout and the production (overseen by non other than Jimmy Page himself) is excellent. The live concerts make up the real weight of time on the DVD but there is a good handful of bonuses too which make great DVD extras. So, what about the concerts themeselves on the DVD:<br /><br />LIVE AT THE ALBERT HALL (1970): This is the only full concert footage on the DVD and it is an absolutely killer capture of the band playing amazing bluesy hard rock from their first two albums. At over an hour and a half in length, the band gave the crowd timeless value for money. Its a great document to show how revolutionary Led Zeppelin were at that time, the crowd seem totally startled by the music and as a result are not as vocal as later crowds to the concerts. You can completely understand this, I myself was more than speechless when I watched it! There's some stellar moments, including the opening hard rocker 'Were Gonna Groove', a track which eventually got a feature on the 'Coda' outtake album. Jimmy Page's guitar work on White Summer/ Black Mountain Side is phenominal to say the least, as is his playing on Dazed and Confused where he plays his guitar with a violin bow! All in all, this concert, on DVD 1, is priceless!<br /><br />MADISON SQUARE GARDEN (1973): The first concert capture on DVD 2 is only of 4 songs but all of them really bring the house down. You can see by this stage how the band's concerts had become much more grander and explosive occasions. The band's performance 'Black Dog' is hair-raising to say the least and you see the crowd really getting into the music and participating in parts. Jimmy Page's guitar work (i'll say it again!) is amazing, especially at the end of 'Black Dog' and at the beginning of 'Since I've Bin Loving You'. Don't fail to notice John Paul Jones' Keyboard work on 'Misty Mountain Hop' either. The band close with 'The Ocean' in great style.<br /><br />EARL'S COURT (1975): This is one of Led Zep's most famous concerts and the 50 or so minute offering of this one shows why. Here we are treated to an acoustic set to start, with 'Going To California', 'That's The Way' and then 'Bron Yr Aur Stomp', which really gets the crowd into the groove. Then we have some stuff from Physical Graffiti, with 'Trampled Underfoot' and the American South themed 'In My Time Of Dying'. The real highlight comes at theend with, yes you guessed, 'Stairway To Heaven'. You see Page's playing on his legendary double-neck guitar and another stirring vocal performance from Plant. This song has become an anthem over the years and it is just amazing to see it played by the band themselves on screen.<br /><br />KNEBWORTH (1979): This is my favourite part of the DVD. The 50 minute capture of part of 1 of the two concerts Led Zeppelin gave at Knebworth in August 1979 is truly amazing. Attended by 1000's, this sadly, would be the last time the band would play in the UK, but what a fitting last time it was! Crashing performances of 'Rock n' Roll', 'Sick  Again' and a finishing 'Whole Lotta Love' medley are timeless. 'Achilles Last Stand' transmits masterfully live, as does 'In The Evening', with Bonham's mystic drumming at the start in tune with loads of strobe lighting. Robert Plant gives his most mature vocal performance here and Bonham drums in phenominal fashion.<br /><br />EXTRAS: Theres a number of extras on either DVD. On DVD 1 there are a number of live performances of 'Communication Breakdown' and 'Dazed And Confused'. On DVD 2, there are a couple of excellent promos of 'Over The Hills And Far Away' and 'Travelling Riverside Blues'. Also there is an interview of Robert Plant where he gives some information on what was the up and coming 'Physical Graffiti' album on the Old Grey Whistle Test. There is also a New York Press Conference where the interviewer asks Plant and Page some really stupid questions - its not surprising how the band ultimately withdrew from doing many interviews!<br /><br />The 'Led Zeppelin' DVD, to put it simply, is awesome. It is a classic 5 hour live take of one of my favourite bands and I have not regretted buying it in the slightest. If you want to see how true hard rock was done by the best, then look no further than this DVD. A must for any fan of the band, you can't be without this DVD!Heaven'. You see Page's playing on his legendary double-neck guitar and another stirring vocal performance from Plant. This song has become an anthem over the years and it is just amazing to see it played by the band themselves on screen.    KNEBWORTH (1979): This is my favourite part of the DVD. The 50 minute capture of part of 1 of the two concerts Led Zeppelin gave at Knebworth in August 1979 is truly amazing. Attended by 1000's, this sadly, would be the last time the band would play in the UK, but what a fitting last time it was! Crashing performances of 'Rock n' Roll', 'Sick  Again' and a finishing 'Whole Lotta Love' medley are timeless. 'Achilles Last Stand' transmits masterfully live, as does 'In The Evening', with Bonham's mystic drumming at the start in tune with loads of strobe lighting. Robert Plant gives his most mature vocal performance here and Bonham drums in phenominal fashion.    EXTRAS: Theres a number of extras on either DVD. On DVD 1 there are a number of live performances of 'Communication Breakdown' and 'Dazed And Confused'. On DVD 2, there are a couple of excellent promos of 'Over The Hills And Far Away' and 'Travelling Riverside Blues'. Also there is an interview of Robert Plant where he gives some information on what was the up and coming 'Physical Graffiti' album on the Old Grey Whistle Test. There is also a New York Press Conference where the interviewer asks Plant and Page some really stupid questions - its not surprising how the band ultimately withdrew from doing many interviews!    The 'Led Zeppelin' DVD, to put it simply, is awesome. It is a classic 5 hour live take of one of my favourite bands and I have not regretted buying it in the slightest. If you want to see how true hard rock was done by the best, then look no further than this DVD. A must for any fan of the band, you can't be without this DVD!

B0006IIKS0|4.0|Most people reading this review know that Metallica has been one of the preeminent thrash bands of the past 20 years - indeed, they were among the first groups to create the very sound we know as thrash.  20 years after their onset, the band found themselves in perilous circumstances once again, with tensions growing between its members.  Jason Newsted, their bass player of 10+ years, had left, and the rest of the band were struggling to recapture their creative drive and fire. <br /> <br />This is where the documentary picks up.  Metallica were in the early stages of recording their first album of new material since 1997's Reload, and they were obviously having difficulties.  The filmmakers capture the odyssey of finding a new bass player and the introduction of band therapy seamlessly into showing the audience where it has led the band to today. <br /> <br />Obviously, the band members had creative control over the doc - who could imagine Lars settling for otherwise? - although they admirably let their dirty laundry air, so to speak.  There are clips of all-out screaming between the members, especially between Lars and James.  The absence of James for a long portion of the film, interestingly, adds tension and introduces traditional dramatic elements to what is supposed to be a documentary.  It makes the film eminently watchable and worth viewing multiple times.   <br /> <br />Basically, if you want a look at what goes on in Metallica's world, this is as good as any of a chance you are going to get.  For non-Metallica fans, it still has value as it's a bit funny hearing the guys talk normally to each other, without any censoring (and believe me, there is a lot to censor), as well as see a vital and dynamic band go through relationship problems.  You can see the band changing and transforming as they learn to channel their anger and frustration in postive ways, and as a result, the working process improves.  Ultimately, it ends on a positive note, with the band releasing their new album St. Anger and embarking on a massive world tour.  Plus, the extras - which include nearly 45 minutes of deleted scenes, all worthwhile, and several interviews with the filmmakers - are well above-average from what you'd normally expect from a DVD.  Simply put, this is a highly entertaining film, whether you are a Metallifan or not.
B000286RNY|5.0|The chopped-up American-release version is pleasant enough, but the real treasure is the original version.  The subtitles often hint at what is actually meant, with the odd word choices making it somehow more entertaining, while Chow and co. often don't need much translation.  Vicki Zhao is a delight to watch, and the film, like so many of Steven Chow's, has a feel very similar to the silent slapsticks of the Buster Keaton/Charlie Chaplin.  The story line is not too different from other Chow movies, although in this one he's pretty likeable from the beginning.  The hurt woman/healing man 'rags-to-riches' romance still works, and there is considerably less blood, but just as much humor.  This is undoubtedly the best Chow movie for American audiences to start with.
B00003CXCT|1.0|It should be painfully obvious to all that Lucas will never stop changing the original Star Wars series.  Why is this, do you ask?  My guess is that he KNOWS that he's lost his spark, his talent, so he's continuing to focus on the only great thing he's ever done in his life and hawk it to a new audience.  There's no other reason for it.  He could have been working on Indiana Jones 4 ten years ago rather than trying to fix something that was never broken.  <br /> <br />I've been hearing people say things like we \\"extremist\\" fans need to get a life and get over the changes. <br /> <br />Why would these extremists not have lives because they don't want their memories stomped on? Lucas NEEDS TO KNOW that his real fans continue to want the original versions released if there's ever going to be a remote chance of him doing so.  You know how he likes to 'change', so there's always a possibility. Simply rolling over and swallowing his garbage will only ensure that he continues to produce it. <br /> <br />Others consider the special editions to be only a small change. <br /> <br />A small change?  I see it more as a series of huge changes. Let me explain how this seems to many of us true fans: The movies have been dissected; they're no longer whole.  They've been, in a word, [adulterated] to the highest degree (but with George the degree can only get higher, so maybe 'highest' is an overstatement).  Speaking for myself, I watch these movies not only for entertainment, but to bring back a NOSTALGIC feeling.  When GL made these changes, he took away the nostalgia of the series.  THAT'S what many fans are bitter over...it's not about thinking that the new versions are horrible, but it's a feeling of betrayal, as if something once great and important during a certain period of our lives has been cast to the wind.  I enjoyed my childhood, and Star Wars was a huge part of it.  It's not healthy to *live* in the past, but we all like to reflect on it from time to time, whether it bethrough music, old toys, or movies.     <br /> <br />Others say that the changes are acceptable to everyone but angry, lonely, borderline sociopaths. <br /> <br />So, everyone who refuses to settle for this insult is an angry, lonely, borderline sociopath?  Give me a break. True fans simply don't take whatever's thrown at them.  If we have a problem with the changes, then we have the right to let it be known.  Such personal attacks on character are not valid. <br /> <br />Changes aside, the sound is also substandard as many reviewers have posted. I didn't actually purchase this abomination myself, but allowed a friend to watch it on my home theater system.  Audio inconsistencies are to be expected when considering the technology of the day.  Sound isn't nearly as easy to alter as video.  The video is much better than the 1997 special editions, but it didn't meet my expectations either. <br /> <br />All in all, if you weren't happy with the special edition changes, save your money for a laserdisc player, check eBay for 'special' deals, or continue to watch the movies on VHS. This set is nothing more than 50 bucks worth of disappointment. <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />

B00008PX8P|5.0|Others have given you the run down on every show and every tune, on Bonham's solo, etc., so I'll just add some comments.    Some people seem not to like Zeppelin at all.  Well, I guess if you don't like Zeppelin you won't like 2 DVD's full of live Zeppelin.     Some people are disappointed that live Zeppelin doesn't sound like studio Zeppelin.  I guess they go to those concerts where the boy bands lip sync their records.  Live performance and studio  recording are two completely different art forms.  Jimmy Page was really into studio work and might put 4 guitar tracks playing at once in a song.  Of course he'll only play one guitar at a time on stage.  The live performance isn't an imitation of the studio recording.  They started playing the tune live before they recorded it in the studio.  Zeppelin puts out a whole lotta music for a 3 piece band.  Page is all over the guitar, Jones is all over the bass, plays two keyboards at once, plays mandolin and stand up bass, and Bonham keeps things moving.  Plant was a rare rock singer who could actually sing.  Some of the tunes in these concerts are encores, the last song of the night, and his voice isn't all rasped out like some rock screamers.      The evolution of the Zeppelin audiences in these shows recorded from 1969 to 1979 is interesting.  In the earliest shows, the audience isn't really into them.  Maybe the audience is a tv audience not into rock, or maybe it's some Danish kids who are just kind of stunned by Plant's over-the-top theatrics and the brooding Jimmy Page.  Then they started picking up a following by 1970 and by 1973 they are riding a huge wave of popularity.  The audience in 75 is similar, but in the last show  from 1979, there's a big audience but something's missing: girls.  The audience is 95%, maybe more, guys.  It's a reflection of the cultural changes of the 70's and also of the consequences of Zeppelin's publicity shyness and reduced touring activity in the late 70's.      It's interesting thatsome people call them the greatest rock band ever, while others feel they have to put them down.  In interviews, they said they just wanted to make some music and have some fun.
B000002UJQ|5.0|One of the best! Radiohead rocks. What a great band, what a brilliant guitarist and singer, the best electronic manipulation in years. Not as good as Kid A, but brilliant.
B0000DDAU9|5.0|Mastodon is insane, violent chaos, like a dying animal thrashing animal attacking everything in sight and making as much noise as possible.  Whereas bands like Meshuggah are chaotic in a machine-like, cold sense, Mastodon is the exact opposite.  This stuff is very organic, the drums ripple and build up and quiet and suddenly explode and are just plain crazy...<br /><br />Mastodon is tough to categorize, but they are defitinely metal and have this bizarre ethnic aesthetic that reminds me of Roman and Greek mythology.  The drummer, Brann Dailor, is simply of the most frenetic drummers I've heard, he is constantly providing tricky cymbal work and fills and just never lets up.  The guitar tone is as low as loud as I've ever heard, providing the \\"crushing\\" feeling another reviewer mentioned.  The vocals are bellowing roars, very unique, very well fit the music.<br /><br />I really don't know what else to say about this band if you haven't heard March of the Fire Ants, go download that, it's how I got into them.  But anyway, if you have heard that song and love it like I did, you can expect a few more tracks in that style on the first half of the album.  Shorter, more straightforward and riff dependant.<br /><br />The latter half of the CD is mostly epics, and contains what I think are the best tracks of the CD.  These songs have clean sections, and possess a beautiful sensitivity not present in the first couple tracks.  The first one of these is \\"Ol'e Nessie\\".  \\"Trainwreck\\" and \\"Trilobite\\" follow suit, and Trainwreck even has a quiet, gasping clean voice in it that sounds very sincere.  These songs bleed sadness, very personal yet vague.<br /><br />Remission has a lot of variety and is very multi-faceted, as well as being extremely technical and heavy.  I especially recommend it to fans of Nile, who has a similar idea behind their music but instead chooses Egypt as inspiration.  Also to fans of Meshuggah and Dillinger Escape Plan, like this band they are technical, metal insanity.  For a long time I forgot I had this... my loss, I guess.cal, metal insanity. B0000AGWJ7|5.0|This is the first of the two epic Avenged Sevenfold CD's, and some would argue that they have 3 (The debut full-length, \\"Sounding the Seventh Trumpet\\") but STST doesn't have the length of this masterpeice and its successor (The controversial \\"City of Evil\\"). When City of Evil came out, there was a lot of mixed feelings, most of them due to comparisons to this album, the critacally acclaimed and well-respected \\"Waking the Fallen.\\" I'm not going to go right out and say one is better than the other, but if you have heard CoE and want to get this one, just know that this cd is much more hardcore-influenced with lots of screaming from vocalist M. Shadows. If you have this cd and are intested in getting CoE, note that City of Evil is much more 80's metal influenced with 99% clean vocals. Now, to Waking the Fallen.    This cd is epic. Avenged Sevenfold go away from the trend of 2 to 3 minute songs and pin lengthy tracks spanning from the upper 4 minute range to nearly 9, I would guess that the average song on this cd is about 5 and a half minutes. If you are unfamiliar with the Avenged Sevenfold sound, then know that they sound similar to what Atreyu would sound like if they're lead singer could actually sing.     1. Waking the fallen -7/10- Its just an opening track, but it is one of the coolest into's I've ever heard.    2. Unholy Confessions -9/10- There is a very good chance that this is the first Avenged Sevenfold you will hear, as it was the first single. While certaintly not their greatest song, this one tells you exactly what A7X is about: great instrumentals, the guitarists (Synyster Gates- Lead, Zacky Vengence- Rhythm) play excellent together, the drum is tight with the rest of the rhythm, nearly inaudible bass, mostly screaming vocals during the verses with a catchy, singing chorus.    3. Chapter Four -9.5/10- This song starts out with some maniac drumming by The Reverend (And this is supposed to be his slow cd!) leads into some great riff and great screaming over singing layered vocals. The name \\"Chapter Four\\" refers to the book of Genisis in the bible, which is what the song is about (For the record they are not a christian band, but they find the bible interesting).    4. Reminissions -9.5/10- Starts out similar to the last song with the drums, but gets to the vocals much quickly as Shadows alternates between screaming and singing. Then, out of nowhere, the middle of the song contains an amazing part where Shadows sings over an acoustic guitar. Great track.    5. Desecrate Through Reverence -9/10- Starts out with a token A7X riff, then after about a minute and a half gets into the vocals. Shadows really shows his voice on the chorus, and then to end out the song he has an amazing singing part... I wish he sang more actually.    6. Eternal Rest -9/10- This song shows the diversity of A7X. First off, who starts out a song with a solo? After Synyster's 20 second part, Shadows screams pull you into a song nothing like the previous 5. They also bring out an organ in this song. An organ! \\"Dark in their hearts, I can feel the burn inside of me\\" that line gives this song a dark, evil feel.    7. Second Heartbeat -9/10- This song was a favorite when it was featured on a couple of compilations before they redid it for this cd. Most people seem to like the original better, I perfer this one, its sligtly slower but the production is much better. This song has more of a punk/metal feel than alot of the other songs on this cd. Another great solo ends another great song.    8. Radiant Eclipse -9.5/10- Most people agree that this is the most underrated A7X song, the best comparison I can give is that most of it is similar to Decesecrate Through Reverence but slower, and then the chorus comes in and Shadows gives you the definitons of \\"soaring vocals.\\" This one and the last are the only songs in this cd with any punk influence.     After the last song, your thinking what else can this band do? You've heard all the previous efforts, eachcompletely different until the last one, which was similar to track 5. You might expect to have more of the same, that you've heard all they can do. If so, you are wrong. Here comes the turning point of this CD.    I Won't See You Tonight (Part 1) -20/10- To start out this track, you hear piano. It seems out of place on this cd, but its there nontheless. Then, you get hammered by the heavy riff. Slower than expected, but not shocking from this band. You brace yourself for the piercing screams, but they don't come. Instead, the mourful, emotional voice of M. Shadows rings in your ear as he sings an amazing song about suicide. Sounds more like a lower-pitched Bruce Dickinson than M. Shadows, as he pours all of his heart and soul out. \\"Sorrow, sank deep inside my blood, all the ones around me, I cared for and most of all I loved, but I can't see myself that way, please don't forget me, or cry when I'm away.\\" An amazing line, Shadows sings it to perfection. This is the epic song, at nearly 9 minutes long. As the static overcomes his voice in the end, you are thrust into part 2.    10. I Won't See You Tonight (Part 2)-12/10- Rising out of the static is an enormous growl from Shadows. This is the response to the suicide commited in the last one, and as the last one is a soft, mournful ballad, this one is a rage of emotions, Shadows sings and screams his heart out, Synyster plays his greatest solo yet, and you hear the chorus from part 1 one last time before this 14 minute two part epic comes to a close.    11. Clairvoyant Disease -9.5/10- IWSYT is a hard act to follow. At the start of this song, Shadows shows you how soft he can go. The whispers in the background give this song depth. There is little hardcore influence in this song, after Eternal Rest there was very little hardcore influence left in the cd. Another great solo. Awesome track    12. And All Things Will End -10/10- The best ending I have ever heard to a cd. This one starts out soft and acoustic, but doesn'twaste any time to get into the thick of things. This song is a straight up metal track. The cd closes with a slowing guitar solo, and your left begging for more.    This cd is simply incredible. Most of the songs I had to give lower scores so I didn't go too high. Also, I should say they didn't \\"steal\\" Overkills logo, there was no copywrite on it, and as for the makeup, well they don't wear it anymore and that does not pertain to the music anyways, which is superb. This cd is unclassifiable, you can call it metalcore or hardcore or whatever but you can always find something in there that makes it not fit. Vocally, Shadows is at his best on this cd (The singing on the new cd, \\"City of Evil,\\" while not bad, comes off as a little whiney due to him trying to sound like Axl Rose, come on Shadows bring back the clean vocals from this cd!). Shadows has one of the best voices out there when he's on form, and it doesn't hurt to have one of the best casts of musicains behind him. The bassist (Johnny Christ) is actually very good, you just can't hear him on this cd. Excellent release, but the best is yet to come from this young band.

While it had some fascinating parts, other parts were dull and I actually found myself skimming the text rather than savoring the words, as I would do with a novel I enjoy.  (The author seems to like lists: lists of zoo animals, lists of contents in lifeboat, lists of maladies of a castaway.)  But mostly, I felt ambivalent about the story.  If it is fiction, then the whole \\"author's note\\" at the beginning is invented and Pi is not a real person.  If it is a true story, then why is it classified by Amazon.com under \\"literature and fiction\\"?  If it is supposed to be an allegory, I feel it has too much realism to work as an allegory (eating tiger feces -- what is allegorical about that?)  If it is supposed to be true-to-life, then what's with the \\"botanical discovery\\" and other such bizarre events?  And the whole thing about his name never becomes relevant to the main events of the story.  I felt the book came closest to making sense with Pi's \\"alternative story\\" at the end, but even that is thrown into doubt by the remainder of the book.  I could not feel for Pi because I could not pull any sense from his confusion.  He suffered, yes, but where exactly is the tragedy?  With the story having so many unstable moments, the narrator becomes unreliable, and I felt like I was being scammed.

Difference is, love and duty called them someplace higher on this one.    A triumphant labor of love.

B000092ZYX|3.0|This album is good, don't get me wrong.  But this is RADIOHEAD we're talking about, the most influential and original band of the 1990s who brought us the BENDS, OK COMPUTER and KID A.  All masterpieces in their own right.  Then after the slightly disappointing AMNESIAC (understandable as it was really KID A's left overs) comes HAIL TO THE THIEF.  HTTT definitely has its share of good songs, whether its the punky Orwell-inspired opener \\"2+2=5\\", the slow, unsettling ballad \\"Sail to the Moon\\", the Classical Gas-like \\"Go to Sleep\\" or the strong first single \\"There There\\", however its biggest problem lies in that there is no unifying theme that the songs share with each other, which in turn makes the album feel more like a messy rarities/b-sides album or, at its best, a greatest hits.  The songs on the Bends were all basically straight-ahead rockers, while tracks on OK COMPUTER all feared the implications of technology in the future and all the electronically conceived tracks on KID A created the sensation of being on another planet. Perhaps Hail to the Thief's hodge-podgy style was what the band were aiming for, because the way in which this album plays out is certainly different to any have done before.  Another problem I had with it was that it also showed signs that their new \\"avant-garde electronic style\\" was already dating, with songs such as BACKDRIFTS and THE GLOAMING falling extremely flat. <br /> <br />If The Bends, Ok Computer, and KID A were all five star albums, Amnesiac a four, and Pablo Honey a two, I see this as about a three and a half.  If IS definitely worth buying if you are a fan however I would strongly recommend their 1995-2000 period material before getting this.

Recently, however, I've become very interested in South Asian literature, and a great many of my friends and sources on the Web were touting 'White Teeth''s Bangladeshi characters as being very well drawn out. So, I decided to get the audio book. If the book sucked, at least it would still keep me engaged in something while I was driving around. <br /> <br />The beginnining of the book is very slow, and goes on for a while about Archie, one of the two main characters. Just as I was losing hope, the Bangladeshi character, Samad appeared. After that, it was off to the races. Smith has the gift of making somewhat unlikable characters into ones the reader completely sympathizes with and cares about. Samad hates the fact he's in England, is a hypocritical pious man, and very rude and short with his family. Yet, I kept wanting to see what would happen next. To me, that is the mark of a truly good book. <br /> <br />The rest of the characters were also very well drawn, and Smith showed the trials and travails they experience as they all grow up in the 80's and 90's. She also has a subtle wit that made me laugh out loud once or twice, but often just left me smiling as I read. The only complaint I had was that the ending scene was a bit abrupt. I would have liked a neater resolution, but this is a small quibble.

Part Time Mutha is a beautiful story about Pac having to raise his kids and also features a sister who speaks of being molested by her father. There are no filler joints on here but people will make a big deal about the production being dated and Im not one of those people. Bottom Line: 2pacalypse Now is one of the best releases of 1991 the most misunderstood rapper in the game. This album showed that he had an awareness of things that most people havent caught on to and still havent caught on to till this day. Anybody who embraces this album and him for what was positive about him are on the right track. All those who embrace Pac for the wrong reasons shouls be ashamed of themselves. Tupac had a level of consiousness that only a few rappers back then had(Paris, Krs-One, Ice Cube, Public Enemy  and X-Clan to name a few). The book brings up some issues about feminism and the role of women in todays society - carrer oriented versus domestic specifically. Clay Cantrell, a hired killer, Spotted Horse, an indian who claims that he can't be killed by a bullet and few others. Crowe always turns in a solid performance and this is no different. He plays a outlaw turned preacher named Cort. Clay Cantrell. <br /> <br />CONTENT: <br /> <br />There is some bad language here but not a whole lot and there is violence of course but it's not very graphic. In this song, Trent Reznor's voice is elevated beyond his usual roar of apathetic angst and enters into an area of romantic crooning - something absolutely different than what he normally does.  Is it shocking?  Yes, but more importantly, it's enjoyable.    The force behind industrial-rock revolutionary band Nine Inch Nails, Reznor has growled and screamed through three studio albums, ten remix albums, several EPs, and a truly angsty live album ever since the band hit the mainstream in 1989 with its first studio album, \\"Pretty Hate Machine.\\"      Throughout the course of listening to \\"With Teeth\\", the band's signature sound of mixing heavy industrial-rock samplings with catchy melodies emanates from beginning to end.  No other song honors this sound better than the album's outstanding first single, \\"The Hand That Feeds You\\", with its pulsating drumming provided by Foo Fighters frontman David Grohl and its politically-driven lyrics.      The majority of the songs are guitar-heavy rock anthems, very similar in style to the band's EP \\"Broken\\" (1992) and the more heavy offerings of \\"The Downward Spiral\\" (1994).  Most fans will feel pleased by this musical direction; the band's last full-length studio album, \\"The Fragile,\\" took the band's sound into a more atmospheric, sublime realm, alienating fans of the band's earlier work.    Reznor went on the record saying that \\"With Teeth\\" would be more \\"song-orientated,\\" unlike \\"The Fragile\\" (1999), which showed more of a focus on dreamy instrumentals spread out between two illustrious disks.  The goal for \\"With Teeth\\" was for each song to sound different than each other, but the album falls short of this goal in the middle stretch.  After \\"The Hand That Feeds\\" each song blends into each other, one large mish-mash of gloomy guitar riffs and percussion.  Luckily, the amazing quality of the album's industrial sound sampling helps the album sound much different than your average rock album, to the benefit of music listeners everywhere.     Though there are similarities between this album and other Nine Inch Nails efforts, the `feel' of the album is completely different, as it normally is between Nine Inch Nails studio albums.  Each song feels much more dense and lyric-heavy than the band's other albums - both a good and a bad thing.  Density equates to the fact that singing accompanies almost every part of each song, and the instrumentals seems to be more focused on servicing the melody.  Sadly, this eliminates some of the sincerity of earlier songs in the band's catalogue; none of the songs reach the sonic majesty of \\"Into the Void's\\" solemn opening or the aching desolation of \\"The Frail.\\"     Luckily, starting with the second-to-last track \\"Beside You in Time,\\" the album enters a much more musically dynamic `zone,' focusing on interesting instrumentals and dreamy vocal looping.  The album ends with \\"Right Where it Belongs\\", an epic personal confessional that ends with a staged live performance.      Even though \\"With Teeth\\" may not be as dynamic as the band's earlier entries, this is a no-brainer for Nine Inch Nails fans and fans of music from any genre.  If you're looking for a more artistically interesting Nine Inch Nails album, any of the other studio albums are sure bets.  But, more than any of the other albums in the band's discography, \\"With Teeth\\" is deadly consistent from beginning to end.  The journey might not go to as many interesting places as before, but that doesn't mean the journey is any less enjoyable.     Dualdisc Extras:  \\"With Teeth\\" has been given the Dualdisc treatment just like \\"The Downward Spiral\\" did last year.  The best feature of the Dualdisc content is a complete discography (or `halography') for Nine Inch Nails, with selected video/song samples.  This is a great bonus for Nine Inch Nails newbies, but pretty useless for the hardcore fans (except for the exert from the extra-rare \\"Closure\\" VHS, Halo 12).    Also included is the video for \\"The Hand That Feeds,\\" which gives fans a glimpse of the post-rehab Trent Reznor rocking with his new band members.  Otherwise, this Dualdisc leaves much to be desired.  With it only costing a couple dollars extra than the standard version, though, the Dualdisc version should be the way to go.  Unless you're like me and you feel weird about handling dual-sided disks.      (...)
B000003TA4|4.0|This album is ok, Smells Like Teen Spirit would be the best song<br /><br />on this, other radio classics would be In Bloom, Come as You Are,<br /><br />& Lithium. Other than those 4, it is rather the weakest CD yet!!<br /><br />I'll rate this CD 4 stars because this is great for those 4.

B00001U0DP|5.0|I first watched this movie in the Spring of 1999.  It was a pivotal time in my life, and the movie fit the period.  At first, I laughed until I cried.  And then...I cried.  I never cry at movies; I laughed during Titanic, only one part got me on Beaches, I hated The Notebook (it was the second movie to make me cry).  The characters in Life is Beautiful are all too real, and human.  It puts a face on something that for many of us is only a memory to our parents and grandparents.  The Holocaust and World War II was one of the scariest times in American history, but oh, how soon we forget.  Life is Beautiful has the capacity to remind us.  I would recommend this movie to anyone over the age of 11.  The subject line is too deep for too many children.  I have not seen the movie in its entirety since that day over six years ago, but this movie changed my life.  I believe that good movies entertain, as well as teach you something.  Life is Beautiful definitely did both.

B0002VEPRQ|5.0|I think this review will be of interest to most people. I'm one of the few people who never saw \\"Mary Poppins\\" as a child. You read that right. I saw it recently for the first time on DVD and here are my impressions of it: firstly, I don't know if I enjoyed this film as much as I would have if I had first seen it as a child. The movie is clearly intended for kids. Yet the film has a wonderful, infectious quality to it. You don't have to be a kid to appreciate it. \\"Mary Poppins\\" is a truly unforgettable film. It has so many things going for it. First is Julie Andrews, who won an Oscar for Best Actress as Mary herself, and who demonstrates supreme self-confidence in this her first starring role.  The film also won an Oscar for Best Special Effects in 1964; the technology to combine live-action footage with animation has since been surpassed (notably in \\"Who framed Roger Rabbit?\\") but it's never been used more effectively than here: that wonderful sequence where Dick Van Dyke dances with a quartet of animated penguins still holds up forty years after it was filmed. Unquestionably, however, the film's greatest asset is its musical score by the Sherman brothers and that score is simply a knockout. Songs like \\"A Spoonful of Sugar\\" and \\"Jolly Holiday\\" are instant classics; once you hear them you will never forget them. And a song like \\"Feed the Birds\\" about the old woman who sits on the steps of St. Paul's cathedral and sells bags of crumbs to feed the birds is truly affecting (\\"though her words are simple and few/ Listen, listen, she's calling to you...\\"). I don't see how anyone can hear a song like that and fail to be touched by it. The film does have its problems: the film's plot is relatively slight: basically, an oblivious and paternalistic father learns to stop being so oblivious and paternalistic.  Indeed, the film's plot comes off as a kind of ad hoc improvisation by the film's creators, just an excuse to string together a series of otherwise-unrelated episodes. Also, the character of Mary has, to my mind, a fundamental flaw (inherited, I believe, from the source material itself, i.e. Pamela Travers' books). It's never really explained why Mary is magical as opposed to any of the other characters.  Apparently, we're just supposed to accept it on principle that Mary Poppins is magical because the movie says she is and then work backwards from that proposition. But all things considered these objections are relatively minor.  The movie generates such joy and good feeling that these things really win the day. One last point: I was aware, prior to having seen the film, that it had gotten a bad rap as \\"treacle\\", \\"syrupy-sweet\\", etc. Not true. What \\"Mary Poppins\\" is is wholesome. It has a simplicity and an innocence to it that you just don't see in movies nowadays. Perhaps we live in a more cynical time. Pity.
B0009ML238|5.0|I don't write reviews for albums on Amazon.com normally, mostly because once I start writing, I can't stop. I wanted to say that it is my opinion that this album is beyond spectacular. I work in a music store in Connecticut, MA, and every time I play this album over the speakers, it sells, or at least arouses the interest of customers. <br /> <br />The main reason I wanted to write this review, however, is to say this: Yea, there are similarities between this band and Dream Theater. But people really should just stop pointing that out. Every modern progressive metal band will sound like, or at least have elements of, Dream Theater. Why is this? It's due to the fact that Dream Theater took all the styles of the 70's prog greats (Kansas, King Crimson, Pink Floyd, Gentle Giant, Emerson, Lake & Palmer, etc.) and combined them together to make their music. It is therefore IMPOSSIBLE for a modern progressive metal act not to sound like Dream Theater. Don't get me wrong, I love Dream Theater. They revived the progressive genre by perhaps the only means possible, and they sounded excellent doing it. I don't care who sounds like who; If it's good, then it's good, and that's that. These newer progressive bands aren't necessarily trying to emulate Dream Theater; they just have the same influences. And so what if they sound similar to Dream Theater!? If you like Dream Theater, then you like Circus Maximus, Ice Age, Threshold, Shadow Gallery, Pagan's Mind, Ivory Tower, Dreamscape, and on and on. Every one of those bands also has their own sounds that they bring to the table. they are by not \\"Dream Theater clones.\\" Circus Maximus is heavier with a lot of Emerson, Lake & Palmer elements, Pagan's Mind is much heavier and honestly has better guitar work (amazing!), Threshold has a much more British feel and is more hard-rock than metal, and Shadow Gallery is softer and a bit more emotional with a lot of piano work and create soothing soundscapes. Stop crying about it, buy the albums, and enjoy them. You can find all sorts of sites, especially the groups' homepages, where you can sample the music. Look at them as something to be appreciated at face value, and don't worry about who they sound like. That's what makes a genre. Groups of bands that all sound similar. And for my money, Circus Maximus' debut is better than anything Dream Theater has released in years. Perhaps even better than Images & Words, and if not, then just as good. If you are looking for bands in the progressive metal genre that are of a bit of a differnt style from Dream Theater and their \\"clones,\\" as you may like to call them, check out Artension, Andromeda, Ark, Evergrey, etc. <br /> <br />This review was not meant to piss anybody off. If it did, and you are someone who wrote a review that this review was targeting, then just think of how much your reviews piss the people off that love these bands that you call \\"Dream Theater wannabes.\\"

First off, this film was filmed where I live, Dubuque, Iowa, was the double for downtown Boston, Dyersville, Iowa is where the field is, and still is to this day. B000A6CLL0|5.0|When Season 3 of Enterprise began, I was extremely anxious to see these new villains, the Xindi. Finding out that there were 5 species of Xindi floored me, but I was amazed by the CGI work for the Xindi-Insectoids and Xindi-Aquatics, as well as the makeup design for the Reptilians and Arboreals, though the Primates weren't too different from us. But then, aren't humans a higher form of primate? <br />Enterprise also went in a slightly new direction by introducing the MACOs, as well as T'Pol resigning her commission with the Vulcan High Command, and getting a new look. <br />The first first few episodes of the season were a little slow at times for my taste, but then the action picked up and the third season experienced a type of action-adventure not seen since Deep Space Nine's Dominion War, culminating in a 3-episode battle to the season's finale, which opened up another amazing storyline into the 4th season, which was unfortunately, the last. <br />I'm not going to provide a summary of each episode, as other reviewers have done this already.   <br />However, it saddens me to note that Star Trek has ended (aside from the fan-mader series), due to a lack of interest. It disheartens me to think that people have come to like those garbage reality shows like 'Survivor' and 'Real Gilligan's Island', not to mention all of the even trashier titles in that genre.   What has happened to us that we are superhypercritical of every episode of a show, when we used to be able to just sit back with a bowl of popcorn and get swept away in the story, and ENJOY it? <br /> <br />Send a message to Hollywood. Stock up on DVDs of GOOD shows, and boycott these awful reality shows. <br /> <br />I intend to spend many hours enjoying Season 3 of Enterprise, and I hope you will too.

His best friend is Abby Taylor (Polly Shannon) and she is one of the best things in the movie.<br /><br />The movie opens with one of the town's few policemen finding a murdered corpse and a live dog.  As the movie progresses there are more murders and it becomes clear that these are the work of a serial killer.  Another plot involves a young schoolgirl who is raped whose mother wants the perpetrators punished, but everything kept confidential because of the shame her family would suffer in such a small town.  The girl caught between her family, the boys who did this to her, and just trying to survive her teenage years.  Jesse does his best to help her as does another policewoman, Molly Crane (Viola Davis).<br /><br />It is a decent movie, but just moves so slowly.  I guess that is to evoke the pace of a small town.  The music emphasizes how quiet and slow everything is as well.  Even at 87 minutes, the movie seems full length.  The performances are good, the story isn't special, but not bad.  Still it takes so much time to get things done.  I would love to have learned more about the personal lives of some of the minor characters and more background on Jesse.  Instead, we get to see a lot of contemplating and drinking of whiskey without much dramatic point to it.<br /><br />If you enjoy seeing Tom Selleck on the screen, and he is always enjoyable to watch, then this is worth the hour and a half.

B0009IW88A|5.0|Anyone who has browses music stores will notice that the film score to \\"The Good, Bad, and the Ugly\\", a film from the 60s, is still selling today.  For anyone who hasn't heard it, the \\"G, B, & U\\" film score is a very complex score that contains many different beautiful themes. <br /> <br />This soundtrack is complex in the same way.  To me it seemed like a bad idea to have two composers collaborate on a score for a blockbuster film but the end result is a score with a 8-10 beautiful and moving themes rather than 1 or 2. I did not really appreciate the depth of this score until I heard it at least a dozen times.  It now ranks among my 3 or 4 favorite scores of all time. <br /> <br />Most great scores are not recognized in their time and this one will probably not receive its due in the form of Oscar recognition.  I do think people will be listening to this score 40 years from now.   <br /> <br />The comparison to the Danny Elfman score is silly.  That was a fun and appealing score but this is pretty serious music appropriate to a more serious movie. <br /> <br />My favorite passages are the last 2 minutes of #2 Eptesicus (beautiful), the last two minutes of #6 Tadarida (sad and beautiful), the first 2 minutes of #7 Macrotus (again beautiful), the first 2 minutes of #8 Antrozous (very stirring), and all of #10 Molussus (again very stirring). <br /> <br />If you are familiar with Hans Zimmer's music you can probably guess which themes are his and which are James Newton Howard's.  Both contributions are equally wonderful. <br /> <br />

B0002JP4L4|5.0|Footloose is viewed with immense affection both by those who remember its original release and new fans alike. It actually deserves that high regard. On the surface, it would be easy to dismiss Footloose as \\"just another teen movie\\": Chicago teen Ren MacCormack (Kevin Bacon in his starmaker role) relocates to small-town Bomont (actually filmed in Provo, Utah). There he finds himself in conflict against a town ordnance forbidding public dancing, primarily in the person of Bomont's Baptist minister (John Lithgow). In the process, Ren romances the minister's daughter Ariel (Lori Singer), engages in a Rebel Without a Cause game of chicken with tractors instead of hotrods, and orchestrates the first high school dance Bomont's seen in years, along the way taking part in some pretty freakin' incredible dance numbers. <br /> <br />Not exactly Citizen Kane material, but elevating Footloose above what it might have been is (a) Dean Pitchford's script never condescends to the characters, (b) all the main characters are portrayed by talented actors investing them with believability and dignity, and (c) wonderful choreography. <br /> <br />Footloose came out just after MTV started up, and it was the right film at the right time, a very early instance of the symbiotic relationship between MTV and movies. To promote Footloose, use of MTV was key. Well before its theatrical release, songs from the soundtrack, the two biggies being Kenny Loggins' \\"Footloose\\" (of course) and Deniece Williams' \\"Let's Hear It For the Boy\\" were cut as videos for MTV. This was one of the first times anyone ever used the idea of a soundtrack, and THE first time they used MTV videos of music from same, to really push a movie into being a major hit. It worked like gangbusters. The soundtrack put six songs into the Top Forty. By the time Footloose hit theaters there was already a nationwide awareness of it, of its music and dance scenes. Immense numbers of people wanted to see the film, and were already disposed to like it, because they loved the soundtrack and videos. <br /> <br />20-plus years later, Kevin Bacon's portrayal of Ren MacCormack is still the role with which he's most identified. Strangely enough, Paramount did not want him in the part. At this point in his career, Bacon was regarded as a character actor, best-known for playing Fenwick in Diner, a very quirky, unhappy young man. So the studio's view of Kevin Bacon was, \\"Yeah, great actor, but for supporting character roles, not possessed of the charisma of a leading man.\\" (Boy, were they wrong.) Veteran director Herbert Ross was already attached to the project, and he believed in Kevin Bacon. That carried weight because Ross was very well-established, had already directed many, many actors to Academy Award winning performances, and said, \\"If Kevin Bacon doesn't get this role I'm walking off the film.\\" Given how things turned out, Ross had to feel incredibly vindicated when Footloose was a smash hit, and because of it Kevin Bacon became a star. <br /> <br />As good as Kevin is as Ren, I have to single out John Lithgow as the Reverend Shaw Moore, Ariel's father and head of the anti-dancing fraternity, for special mention. It would have been so easy for the writer and director, and Lithgow, to portray Moore as the villain of the piece, a caricature, a stereotype, the narrow-minded, Bible thumbing, overbearing Baptist minister. Instead he's really the beating heart of the movie, a kind, decent man whose son died in a car crash several years before, and as a result he's become extremely protective and over-controlling of his daughter's life. This is something people can understand as a very human reaction, motivated by love even if it expresses itself badly. Lithgow's portrayal of Rev. Moore and the story of his troubled relationship with his daughter gave Footloose its crossover appeal, turning it from \\"just another teen movie\\" into something adults could watch and enjoy, as well. <br /> <br />Diane Wiest isexcellent in the small but crucial role of Vi Moore, the Reverend's wife. Chris Penn is just amazingly good as Ren's new friend, Willard Hewitt. Some of the most indelible imagery in Footloose, what comes to mind first whenever I think of it, are the scenes where sophisticated, worldly-wise Ren takes awkward, small town Willand and teaches him to dance. Lori Singer is great as Ariel, the wild child who's sexy, angry, and sweet by turns. Really there are no slackers in this movie, every major role is filled by actors who totally inhabit their characters. <br /> <br />Not to put more weight on this piece of mass market entertainment than perhaps it can support, but at its heart Footloose does ask the question \\"What is moral behavior?\\" Is it unswerving adherence to a preset code of conduct, or do we have a moral responsibility to judge the status quo, and if our sense of morality says we must, rise up against it? Footloose is about people, in a small way, on a grass roots, real world level, fighting against oppression, a sort of spiritual/intellectual lockstep mentality. <br /> <br />So that's Footloose. A film that, once you start digging into it, is really one hell of a lot more than \\"just another teen movie.\\" But in the course of doing all that impressive stuff, it never forgets how to entertain and have fun. The DVD has superb extras, including the original trailer; commentary tracks by Kevin Bacon, producer Craig Zadan and writer Dean Pitchford; and three \\"making of\\" featurettes. I would have liked to see the videos for \\"Footloose\\" and \\"Let's Hear It For the Boy\\" and the Kevin Bacon audition tape \\"cut like a rock video\\" mentioned in one of the featurettes (assuming it still exists) included as extras. Oh well, maybe in a future special edition. For now, Footloose is definitely a movie worth owning on DVD.
