B00003CXCT|3.0|I was too young to watch Episodes IV and V in the bigscreen, but one of my most vivid childhood memories consisted of watching Episode VI in the theater and being utterly amazed.  I will always remember the Episode VI musical numbers with great nostalgia, for all their corniness and camp.   <br /> <br />Though I understand the frustration that George Lucas must have felt when he couldn't realize his vision completely because of a lack of technology, I still wish that he would have had more consideration for his original fan-base when he released, under great anticipation, the Original StarWars Trilogy.  It was disappointing to  see scenes that were particularly nostalgic for me doctored up or just eliminated.  While I understand that the new version of the films maybe closer to Lucas' original vision for the films and that new fans have been exposed to a wonderful trilogy because of these advancements, it would be nice if Lucas could follow Peter Jackson's approach regarding film versions.  Both versions of each of the LOTR films are available for fans and Lucas should follow suit.  I'm not quite sure why he hasn't adopted this policy, since it would only provide him more money in the long run, as well as pleasing both the old and new fans.   <br /> <br />Until that time, however, when I want a DVD experience, I watch the new version, fast-forwarding through the new scenes that have replaced the ones I dearly missed.  Yes, I miss the lippy muppet lady singing in a strange language that seems an odd mix of Spanish meets Russian.  Being a musician, I think it a more creative and musically more interesting composition than the new musical number. But when I want to relive those special scenes, the scenes that enspire that wry grin that recalls \\"youth\\", \\"silliness\\", and I believe Lucas' ingenuity to make due and create a wonderful story with what he had, I revert back to a set of very old, very worn video tapes.  Thank goodness they still make VCRs.  Don't get me wrong,there are parts of the new version that I think are great; the addition of more creatures being one.   <br /> <br />So, please, new fans, don't think that we old fans are nuts or just not open to change.  Just imagine, in 15-20 years, when there is a new form of video technology and Lucas comes out with a new version of STARWARS, and again changes the movie, and doesn't release the version you grew to love and respect.  Maybe then, you'll understand why we are so disappointed and sad, and why we've reviewed this trilogy so poorly.

B0007Y08IS|5.0|When you combine South Park creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone with a horde of marionettes, what do you get?  Team America: World Police begins with an elite counter terrorism squad recruiting a broadway actor who has a tragic past.  As the film unfolds, Team America comes under fire from protesting Hollywood types, as well as evil dictator Kim Jong Il, who has set in motion a plan to destroy every major city in the world.  Oh yeah, in the middle of all this, the viewer is shown two of these puppets going at it, which is one of the most irreverant and hilarious things you'll ever see.  Offensive to no end, deliberately politically incorrect and tongue in cheek, and one of the funniest films to be released in some time, Team America finds Parker and Stone crafting something other than a seemingly one trick pony animated show.  Deliriously funny, Team America isn't for everyone, but for fans of the South Park creators and absurd comedy, this is something really special and surprisingly smart.

B0002IVN9W|4.0|If the appeal of the Arcade Fire's music could be expressed in a simple mathematical equation, it would probably go something like: Emotional directness + musical intricacy=goodness.  With the emotive wailing of Win Butler backed by the eclectic sounds of a decidedly diverse collective of musicians, their debut full-length Funeral is an unconventional, unpredictable, and occasionally thrilling work that actually manages to stake the band some territory of their own in an increasingly glutted indie world.  Even when this album falls short of the high standards set by its best moments, its missteps are still marked by ambition rather than laziness, so they're easy to forgive.  Huge melodies, swells of orchestration, and female vocals abound, and while I don't doubt that such a sound could easily be mangled in lesser hands, the Arcade Fire's undeniable sincerity and detailed songwriting style manage to carry them through any potentially lame spots.  In their better moments, they pull off stuff that previously only the Shins and the Flaming Lips could get away with.<br /><br />The Arcade Fire are considerably more original than such retro-cool hipster acts as Interpol and Franz Ferdindand (to say nothing of the laughably derivative likes of Jet), and their sound has a musicality that seems to be lacking in much of indie music these days.  Even when similarities to other bands pop up (the oft-mentioned Pixies, the Smiths, and the Dismemberment Plan come to mind), these guys have a knack for only taking the best aspects of their influences to form their own genre-bending creation.  Perhaps more importantly, while there are tons of orchestral elements incorporated throughout, this is still very much a rock album.  True, some songs are softer than others, and things can occasionally get a bit overwrought for this reviewer's tastes, but their frequent dense arrangements and puunchy rhythms ensure that the Arcade Fire never quite veer into the unbearably wimpy territory occupied by such sexually ambiguous sissy bands as Belle and Sebastian and Death Cab for Cutie.  This fact is evident right away on the hard-charging opener Neighborhood #1 (Tunnels), and it's only made more apparent on the subsequent Neighborhood #2 (Laika) and Neighborhood #3 (Power Out), which even had me bobbing my head to the sound of a xylophone.  No small achievement, that.<br /><br />In the end, the Arcade Fire's everything-but-the-kitchen-sink approach is a rousing success, making for one of the most accomplished albums of 2004 and a debut that puts them right up there with the Shins and Modest Mouse among the indie world's leading lights.  With the tragic news that the much-revered (by me, anyway) McLusky recently disbanded, I've been looking for a new rock band to worhsip, and while these guys don't quite fit the bill yet they could be well on their way.  Even if you're highly skeptical of indie-world darlings, you owe it to yourself to give these guys a shot and at least come to your own decision.  A flavor-of-the-month hipster band the Arcade Fire is not.ccupied by such sexually ambiguous sissy bands as Belle and Sebastian and Death Cab for Cutie.  This fact is evident right away on the hard-charging opener Neighborhood #1 (Tunnels), and it's only made more apparent on the subsequent Neighborhood #2 (Laika) and Neighborhood #3 (Power Out), which even had me bobbing my head to the sound of a xylophone.  No small achievement, that. <br /> <br />In the end, the Arcade Fire's everything-but-the-kitchen-sink approach is a rousing success, making for one of the most accomplished albums of 2004 and a debut that puts them right up there with the Shins and Modest Mouse among the indie world's leading lights.  With the tragic news that the much-revered (by me, anyway) McLusky recently disbanded, I've been looking for a new rock band to worhsip, and while these guys don't quite fit the bill yet they could be well on their way.  Even if you're highly skeptical of indie-world darlings, you owe it to yourself to give these guys a shot and at least come to your own decision.  A flavor-of-the-month hipster band the Arcade Fire is not. <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />

0375507256|4.0|David Mitchell is a really smart writer.  Cloud Atlas is his third novel (I believe) and extremely well written.  I judge books based on writing, characters, and then plot; this book exceeding my expectations in all three sections.  Because he offers such a variety - all sections cannot honestly please everyone.  For me, the first and third plots didn't hit it; but I read them in amazement, not believing that the same man could drastically morph his style so seemlessly.  And where two didn't quite please me, the other four AMAZED me.  I really like this author.   <br /> <br />I recommend this book if you want to think.  It's not a mystery, not that kind of thinking; but most of it is not \\"easy reading\\"...it's smart reading.  The first section is really difficult - you don't need to understand everything.  It probably will not draw you in, but get past the first 10 pages and you'll be used to this section's style.  And after that, you'll be sucked into it all.  Enjoy.

0767812166|5.0|This movie has the distinction of being the only John Carpenter film to earn an Oscar nomination.  STARMAN is a wonderfully enjoyable movie with Jeff Bridges garnering a Best Actor nomination for his role as the starman, who gets stranded on earth and takes on the form of a young woman's dead husband.  Karen Allen, in her best role, is the widow and she is a perfect match for Bridges' genial alien.  Bridges is a delight to watch as he takes on the mannerisms of a human being; his naivete, innocence and pure goodness radiates the film.  Allen's conflict in how she feels about this alien is also beautifully played out, and by the time the movie comes to its inevitable conclusion, we've been given a rather unique love story to boot.  Charles Martin Smith is good as the government employee who has to battle the war mongering Richard Jaeckel to ensure Bridges' safety.  Bridges scene with the killed deer is also touching.  The movie is like a grown up version of ET, and while it wasn't nearly as successful, STARMAN is one of John Carpenter's finest films.
0393035158|3.0|The premise of Dr. Harris's book seems to be that civilization can no longer survive with religious faith as a part of its makeup. Why? Harris believes that in an age of nuclear proliferation, some religious zealot will get his or her hands on an atomic weapon and destroy the world in the name of God. He makes the case that because of irreconcilable differences, people of different faiths are incapable of living peacably together. Too much is at stake (the soul) and too many of these people are willing to die or kill for what they believe in. Therefore, humanity must abandon religious faith as an acceptable path to spiritual fulfillment and enlightenment.<br /><br />I find Harris's arguments flawed. I happen to be a Christian. One of my neighbors is a devout Muslim. We live together peacably. I may not belive that his faith is the true spiritual path and I am quite certain that he feels the same about me. But neither of us has any desire to kill the other. Anicdotal evidence perhaps, but it does make a point. Harris is using a \\"blame the gun\\" argument here. People who kill in the name of God use religion as a justification for their barbaric and diviant behavior. Take away religion, and these twisted individuals will simply find another excuse to act out in a similar manner. Others have used warped political ideologies, and twisted scientific theories to justify the killing of their fellow human beings. Should we dispense with politics because some crazed facist might decide to start World War III out of a megalomanic desire to rule the globe? Should we ban scientific pursuits out of a fear that some environmentalist nut might launch a crackpot scheme to rid the earth of \\"parasitic\\" humans? I think not.<br /><br />What does Harris offer as a solution to this problem? He believes that through the application of reason, we can solve our differences and save ourselves from distruction. Anything, which prevents an \\"open\\" expression of opposing views, should be considered unacceptable. Yet, Harris's view is that any beliefs that conflict with his Humanistic ideology should be maginalized, if not erradicated. Therefore, everyone must embrace Humanism first. How he would accomplish this, I don't know. On a recent Book TV program, Harris claimed that he is not advocating the forced extermination of persons of faith, and I believed his sincerity. But people are not going to reliquish deeply held religious beliefs just because someone claims it mould be better for everyone if they did so. The only way to bring about this atheistic utopia would be through coercion, a policy that has been followed by such peace-loving nations as China, Iran, and North Korea, just to name a few. Let me point out that it has not worked in those countries anymore than it did in the former Soviet Union. Certainly, were we to outlaw religion tomorrow, very few of the men and women who appeared in church last Sunday would be seen there this week. Fear of persecution would dissuade most from attending, but surely, not all would allow their fear to dictate either their behavior or beliefs. Thousands would remain faithful and retain the courage of their coinvictions in the face of adversity and that courage would attract new converts, as it always does. What would Harris do about them?<br /><br />Harris did admit, on the same program, that he is not a pacifist, so he is leaving the door open (if only ajar) for the use of violence. Harris also stated that there was nothing anyone could say to Osama Bin Laden to change his mind about Islam, implying that the only way to deal with such a person was to kill him. I agree that Bin Laden should be eliminated, and the sooner the better, but because he is a homicidal maniac bent on massacring innocents, not because he refuses to renounce Islam.<br /><br />Finally, Harris demands that we apply evidence to our beliefs and abandon them, should they be disproved. In that spirit, let me subject Harris's own argument to that same standard. Admittedly, I cannot prove the existance of God. However, Harris and his humanistic friends cannot disprove that existance either. Likewise, Harris believes that because mankind is a being capable of reason, he is worthy of trust. However, I can point to a multitude of examples throughout the length and breadth of human history, which demonstrates that mankind has never been trustworthy. No thank you, Dr. Harris. Let's say you are correct about God being nothing more than a product of the imagination. Well, if I die trusting in an \\"imaginary\\" God to save an immortal soul, which I do not possess, I lose nothing. However, should I trust my life to the goodwill of my fellow man, and I am betrayed, (a demostrably likely event) than I just might lose the only existance that I will ever have.that same standard. Admittedly, I cannot prove the existance of God. However, Harris and his humanistic friends cannot disprove that existance either. Likewise, Harris believes that because mankind is a being capable of reason, he is worthy of trust. However, I can point to a multitude of examples throughout the length and breadth of human history, which demonstrates that mankind has never been trustworthy. No thank you, Dr. Harris. Let's say you are correct about God being nothing more than a product of the imagination. Well, if I die trusting in an \\"imaginary\\" God to save an immortal soul, which I do not possess, I lose nothing. However, should I trust my life to the goodwill of my fellow man, and I am betrayed, (a demostrably likely event) than I just might lose the only existance that I will ever have.

0156027321|5.0|Reading a back page of Life of Pi, I found myself saying, \\"A boy with a tiger on the boat in the middle of the ocean? Ridiculous. That would never happen.\\" Life of Pi proved me wrong.<br /><br />Still not quite sure whether the story was based on the true events, though the author certainly presented it so. If it is true, my hat is off both to the survivor of getting lost and having only a tiger for the companion, and to the author who was able to transform this experience into a hugely entertaining book.<br /><br />Rarely do we see the characters so engaging in any work of fiction. Pi, in his unobtrusive way, starts out the story by whispering to us of animal behavior and his childhood adventures, of his desire to love God in all religions and of his secular Indian family. Only gradually do we find ourselves thoroughly invested in his survival, at the point where it is in most peril.<br /><br />And the tiger!!! Oh, the tiger is magnificent. Pi speaks of him with a mixture of love and anger, which only comes from living with a thoroughly dangerous beast who is also your only companion.<br /><br />One thing that points me more toward - maybe this did happen after all? - it's hard to come up with all the realistic details regarding surviving alone in the middle of the ocean, such as skin problems related to being surrounded by the salty water and being constantly under the sun. It's also hard to figure out a good way to kill turtles when you don't have that many useful tools at your disposal. You kind of have to have been there to learn all those rules to live by.<br /><br />Throughout, the book is founded in the science of biology and thorough knowledge of religions. And although the book begins with, \\"I'll tell you a story that will make you believe in God,\\" it did something better for me: it made me believe even more in the power of man to overcome anything.

B00005JL78|4.0|Before filming began, Steven Spielberg created a \\"think tank\\" of scientists, physicists etc to basically brainstorm what would the future be like, from transportation to home movies to advertising. It's an eerily real picture, as if someone went into the future and came back and told everyone what he saw. So we have Spielberg's first action blockbuster since the Lost World and it's not in the same category as E.T or Jaws but it's still an entertaining romp. <br /> <br />Less than 50 years from now, the Precrime Unit uses the psychic abilities of 3 clairvoyants to determine when someone gets murder so it's up to the police to stop it from happening. But this creates a debate: is someone a murderer if they haven't done it yet? John Anderton believes in its system until he becomes the murderer of someone he's never met. Instead of just getting arrested, he decides to do what they others don't get to do: figure out why he's going to kill him meanwhile being hunted by Precrime's other policemen. <br /> <br />It's a future that seems quite possible. Instead of advertisements on TV, electronic scanners scan your eyes than proceed to advertise their products/services and actually address you. Getting on a train gets you scanned. They even have small Spyders which can also scan rather than policemen doing it themselves. <br /> <br />Transportation systems have electronic cars magnetized(said in the bonus features) and they can travel up and down buildings. Instead of men building cars, it does it all by itself. These and many more are featured in the film and helped along by Spielberg's think tank.  <br /> <br />Now for the film itself. It's merely a good movie. It's not awesome like Jaws, or great like Close Encounters, it's merely good. Close Encounters had a 2 and a half hour pacing but never felt it, here it almost feels it(same length). Also while Jaws freaked you out and scared you and Jurassic Park gripped you, this just merely entertains you. It's like it doesn't getyou pumped about the action scenes, it's like \\"ooh an action scene\\" but you don't get anything afterward. <br /> <br />Tom Cruise can be a good actor if he had the right character. Ever see Magnolia? He's actually surprising in that. Sometimes actors think the best way to act is just to have a big serious face the entire film so it looks like you're deep in thought and troubled. Robert De Niro and Al Pacino can just do one facial expression and they say more than a big overracted speech. Tom Cruise kind of pulls it off, getting better as the film continues. The rest do their job but they merely play static characters, providing a certain type of attitude, so you have the estranged and little bitter wife, the \\"I'm gonna get you\\" government agent and the father-ly runner of Pre-Crime. <br /> <br />If you're thinking of another Spielberg masterpiece think again. But it's close enough and even a near masterpiece is more better watching than the recent fare plaguing movie theatres(I'm looking at you The Pacifier, Monster-in-Law and Shark Boy and Lava Girl)

It has more adult themes in it.<br /><br />The film is about a revolutionary candy-maker that goes by the name of Willy Wonka(Johnny Depp). After leaving his father and settling off on his own, he starts a candy factory where it settles to make the best candy in the world. After a worker of the factory leaks out a secret formula for a new candy, Wonka fires all of the human workers and places the job of making the candy in the hands of the Oompa Loompas and machines. He then secludes himself into the factory, until one day he sends out five golden tickets in five separate packages of Wonka Bars for five kids to find. They would be able to tour the factory with this ticket. When all of them are suddenly eliminated, leaving one child, Charlie(Freddie Whitmore). Wonka is giving a offer to Charlie to run the factory when he is dead and gone, but Charlie has something that Wonka doesn't, a family.<br /><br />Tim Burton has entirely taken over the story that was written by Ronald Dahl. The style of the film is clearly Burton's. It was quirky, weird, and strange, but strangely funny. Tim Burton's direction really helped make the story feel more realistic and fun. Albom would do well to stick to 'Jordan was 11 of 17 and perfect from the free throw line.' <br /> <br />There's a little section in the front of the book modestly entitled \\"Lives Changed by 'Tuesdays With Morrie'\\".  In it we learn that people are reading Ablom's work to children and students.  Folks, please . . . . this is a very, very depressing book about death. Plus the kids will go to sleep tonight not worrying about the day when she/he can no longer wipe their own butt (second person butt wiping being a major theme in \\"Tuesdays\\"). <br /> <br />Listen, Morrie faced death courageously and I kind of feel like I'm insulting the guys memory by knocking this book. Depressing, disease ridden, finding joy in sorrow, touchy feely, TV movie of the week stuff. B00003CXAA|5.0|I'm not quite sure if it's possible to surpass THE GODFATHER series in terms of pure artistic beauty. The imagery is wrought with the emotions of the film and the characters, the Italian-language moments are scripted well and interjected at the best times, and the acting (among other things such as the directing and cinematography) is superb. It's a travesty, it really is, that Al Pacino never won an Oscar for these films. The extras, including commentaries, are very well done and don't ruin the integrity of the film, as so many DVD extras often seem to do. <br />I've loved these films since I was a little girl; even then, I was able to discern the circumstances and fabulousness of the characters. This is due to Francis Ford Coppola's unceasing vision. Although Part III is clearly the least of the trio, it is the necessary conclusion that the series needs. Perhaps if it had been brought to the screen sooner after Part II, the vision would have been less interrupted. However, all three are remarkably well done -- I hate to repeat myself, but nothing surpasses THE GODFATHER.
0440419514|2.0|I started this series, and after reading the first book, The Golden Compass, was certain that the shining reviews were correct, that this indeed was another landmark fantasy series like LOTR.  I excitedly recommended it to friends, and started on The Subtle Knife.  Despite brilliant scenes, it was definately looser than the first, but still very good.  The third book, The Amber Spyglass, however, completely fell apart.  It was such a huge let down in fact, that I feel cheated, which is why I'm giving this series 2 stars. <br />For those of you who haven't read it yet, you'd better stop here. <br />For those of you who have already made your judgement that I'm really just a disgruntled Christian, and that your beloved masterpiece is beyond logical reproach, you can stop here too. <br /> <br />Why didn't I like The Amber Spyglass?  Pullman pulls in so much superfluous crap into the third book that he can't tie together, that it bursts open like a bale of hay.  To deal with this, he changes the nature of characters with senseless glee, leaves gaping inconsistencies and loose ends, and worst of all, he spends two and a half books preparing the reader for a dramatic battle that never occurs.  Why?  Because it seems that as if in the last book, Pullman decides that he hates God so much that he can't even bring himself to make God a formidible enemy, so he quickly disposes of God and his Cosmic Meathead Orderly with a few casual pages, and changes course.  No, these divine enemies are way too pathetic.  Forget that the entire series has been building toward fighting them.  No, Pullman brushes them aside, and makes the TRUE enemy human nature. Selfishness, lust for our own desires, all the things that led to the making and use of the knife, the loss of dust, and the creation of Spectres.  These are the enemy.  But isn't it funny how these same exact \\"values\\" are what cause Lyra to \\"fall\\" thereby saving the universe.  And what did happen there exactly? The consciousness of the universe was so interested in a pair of copulating 12 year olds that it stopped draining into nowhere?  And despite this, it was still necessary to close all the the windows except for 1, not 2 mind you, but 1?  All so we can have the heart rending dollar store tear jerker at the end?  Sorry, the implausible, unexaplainable things that arose in the last book was just too much. <br />While reading the last book, I had no idea where it was going.  I kept waiting for a climax that never came.  I was so excited about the prospect of watching God get an ass-whoopin (as prophesized), I barely realized He died.  It was like a tarp blew out of my truck while I was driving down the highway, and I realized several miles down the road it was gone.  I kept thinking, \\"So is it over?\\"  But it wasn't.  It dragged on with the excitement of hung-over teenagers packing up their campsite after a night a partying in the woods.  And, in a truly astonishing finale, Pullman slaps his devoted readers in the face by taking these two 12 year old children who have saved the universe, whom you have come to love, and who have defied all natural and celestial laws with human ambition, love, and loyalty...All of a sudden they are forced to stand down, accept the authority of...the limitations of the physical universe, be bound to its rules and their own chosen concern for the lives and well-being of others, (is this starting to sound like Christian values here, I'm getting teary eyed) and force themselves apart in a monumental act of self restraint and sacrafice (wasn't it Mary, the serpent, who scoffed at these notions while tempting Lyra? ).   <br />The last book presents a loosely assembled, muddled casserole of conflicting ideas, unbelievable sequences of events, and totally contrived, unneccesary drama.  The deterioration in writing from the first book to the last is remarkable, but by that time, many readers are so infatuated with Pullman's characters and worlds, they simply fail to notice.

B0002IU988|4.0|When I heard that the members of Creed minus Singer Scott Stapp would be forming a band of their own I expected very simply \\"Creed 2\\".  This was easy for how could a band where the core writer and co founder of Creed would be forming this new project.  Mark Tremonti was already ready with this recording just a few months after the announcement of Creed's breakup was announced.  Joining Tremonti (who would be on guitar still) would be Scott Phillips (drums) and Brian Marshall (bass).  Mark and Scott had been in Creed for all three albums while Marshall had left after \\"Human Clay\\".  Joining the three on vocals would be Myles Kennedy formerly of the Mayfield Four.  As I listened to the CD it was immediately apparent that this group would not be an exact copy of Creed and I based this primarily on the difference in vocal register of Kennedy.  While Stapp held a deeper resonance that was often compared to Eddie Vedder of Pearl Jam, Kennedy seems to be able to reach notes that Chris Cornell would pull off with ease.  A lot of the music is Creed-like and I expected this much for ones writing style would usually take some larger amount of time to change into something different.  It is my belief that had Creed remained together that some of these songs would have been on the new album.  The similar musical sound surely can appeal to the existing Creed fans.  The name \\"Alter Bridge\\" is drawn from a personal point in Tremonti's childhood based on paths and choices.<br /><br />The band has had tracks from the album featured on the soundtracks to both \\"Elektra\\" and \\"Fantastic Four\\" and this is sure to assist them in building a larger fan base.  While I enjoyed the CD for the most part especially due to tracks like \\"Open Your Eyes\\" and \\"Shed My Skin\\" I have to wonder if the existing Creed Legions will take to this in the same manner as the predecessor.  The band clearly is solid and the production on the release is nice and heavy at time.  So I hope they don't pass on it merely waiting on Scott's debut as a solo artist.  There are a good enough number of tracks on the CD to merit purchase so I advise them to check it out.  Songs such as \\"Down To My Last\\" can easily find their way on the radio stations as simply as a track like \\"Higher\\" and \\"One Last Breath\\".  I say this as someone who was also skeptical in the beginning and now finds himself playing the CD regularly.rely waiting on Scott's debut as a solo artist. B0007GAERG|4.0|Has 2005 been the return of female R&B? Amerie tempted us to \\"Touch\\" her with a catchy single, Faith Evans stepped out of her late husbands shadow to become a formiddable R&B force, Tweet announced \\"It's Me Again\\" and no one cared, while Keyshia Cole attempted to become the next Mary J. Blige in training. However none of the above mentioned artist had an album that was more anticipated and with higher expecations than Mariah Carey. On her 8th studio album (10th LP overall), 15 years in the game & a plethora of  #1 singles, what more exactly does Mariah have to offer us?  <br /> <br />Let me start of by saying one thing. I'm not a Mariah freak that thinks everything she has ever put out is golden nor am I a Mariah hater that cringes everytime \\"One Sweet Day\\"  or her numerous other #1 singles play on the radio. I have always taken Mariah on a case by case basis. So with that said we review Mariahs latest work \\"The Emancipation of Mimi\\". <br /> <br />A lot was riding on \\"The Emancipation of Mimi\\". After the disaterous Glitter (which did eventually go  platinum) and the dismal follow-up \\"Charmbracelet\\" Mariah had to rethink her strategy. Carey said \\"Charmbracelet\\" was a result of her record label wanting her to harp on her \\"breakdown\\" and sing her swan song about making it \\"Through The Rain\\". So when Mariah did eventually make it through the rain, it was time for Mimi to be emancipated.  <br /> <br />Fresh off his hot streak with Usher, Jermaine Dupri laced Mimi's catchy first single \\"It's Like That\\". It was a certified club-thumper with catchy clapping, loving life lyrics and a memorable chorus. The song peaked at #12 on the charts. Mariah has always been a decent songwriter and she has written her own material since the inception of her career however one has to wonder why at age 35 she feel's the need to spout lines such as \\"Those chickens are ash and I'm lotion\\", and flaunt her bling like when she talks about picking up her Louis Vuitton on \\"Shake it off\\" or havinga house in Capri on \\"Get your number\\". Perhaps the gem of the album is the other J.D produced hit \\"We Belong Together\\". The Emancipation of Mimi was hailed as \\"The Return of The Voice\\" in ad campaigns and while Mariah says the voice has always been there it's never been more evident than on this track. The song opens with a dramatic piano intro eventually launching Mariah into song about letting her true love go, and the heartache it is causing her. Contrary to popular beliefs that the songbirds vocals have been permanently damged there is no evidence of that here becauseMariah sings in full voice throughout the song however she avoids vocal theatrics laxing her vocals where needed and belting where neccesary. The song became her 16th #1 single and pushed \\"Mimi\\" back to the top of the album charts a month after it's release.  <br /> <br />\\"Shake it off\\" is a nice summer groove. Maybe it isn't the most lyrically innovative track of Mimi's career however if you just want to enjoy a fun song \\"Shake it Off\\" will serve that purpose. On \\"Mine Again\\" Mariah takes the \\"We Belong Together\\" route again talking about hopefully reuniting with a lost love. The instrumentation on the track is brilliant as are Mariah's vocals with better than average \\"I miss you please be with me again\\" lyrics and smooth horn's and piano. The Emancipation of Mimi would not be a Mariah Carey album without hip hop appearnaces which have become a staple of her career since \\"Fantasy\\" her trail-blazing track with the now deceased O.D.B. Before Ashanti had Ja Rule, Mariah was alreadying making Hip-Hop/R&B duets a main stay on pop radio. (Check out Heartbreaker, Honey etc.) \\"Say Somethin\\" is as \\"Neptunes\\" as songs come these days, and if anyone has the \\"Tasty\\" LP by Kelis (yes the milkshake girl) the beat for this song came straight off of that album. Out of all the tracks featuring rappers on this album this one is the catchiest mainly because Snoop and Mariah have always sounded good together and the playful lyrics between the two make for an engaging song. \\"Get Your Number\\" is an attempt at another club-banger a la \\"It's Like That\\" however for me the song just never caught on. Mariah's cooing at the intro set's up the song, however after that the song just cruieses into mediocrity. On \\"One and Only\\" Mariah is looking for that special one after a disasterous relationship. Lyrically it's one of the better tracks on the album with Mariah looking for a man that will \\"Rub her slow and make her sing real high when he goes down low\\". \\"One and Only\\" would actually be a very good track however Twisters appearance kills it for me but if you can look past that for a quality song you'll find one here.  <br /> <br />Much in demand Hip Hop heavyweight Kanye West lends his production talent to one track on the album with the stellar \\"Stay The Night\\". It's a radio friendly track with a mid tempo groove a la Alicia Keys \\"U don't Know My Name\\" and Janets \\"I Want You\\". Mariah talks about being at a friends house that she has always been attracted to. She knows he is involved with someone yet he keeps insisting that she \\"Stay the night\\", although Mariah is hesitant becausedoesn't trust herself or what could happen. Vocally she's better on this track than on \\"We Belong Together\\". <br /> <br />Ballad \\"Circles\\" produced by Jimmy Jam of produciton duo Flyte Tyme (Janet's\\"Control\\") is as vulnerable as Mariah gets on this album. An ex-flame has Mariah a hot mess, not knowing what do do with herself running around in circles and tumbling down. She hits the infamous Carey high note on this song and it fits in surprisingly well. Lyrically it's raw and honest and another notable vocal performance. The following track \\"Your Girl\\" is fun. It's one of the most enjoyable songs of the album and one of the ones that works best with an upward groove and soaring vocals. Throughout the song Mariah assures us that she will do anything in her power to assure the man she is pursuing that she can be hisgirl including make him think those \\"naughty\\" thoughts.  \\"I wish You knew\\" another Jimmy Jam track, is classic because of the live feeling added to it. Mariah has a cheering audience and engages in some dialogue with them. She's shrieking in full force on this song and while at sometimes it feels a bit over the top she manages to pull it off. The song is very retro and again the lyrics are pleasant and listenable. After all if Beyonce can get song writing props for writing \\"And I won't diss you on the internet, cuz my mama taught me better than that\\" (from \\"Survivor\\") than Mariah can definitely receive some for the bulk of the songs on \\"Emancipation\\". \\"To The Floor\\" featuring Nelly is the last of the uptempo tracks and another attempt by Mariah to make a dance friendly club track. While the track isn't a total miss the production is a little stale and the song lacks a memorable chorus. Nelly's flow is nice however it does little to revive the otherwise passable track. <br /> <br />Mariah closes the album with two ballads. \\"Joy Ride\\" is a soft whispery jam that finds Mariah singing in one of her lower registers throughout the song while bursting into that glass shattering note at the end. Mariah is on a natural high in this song over the joy she has found with her latest love. Nothing could ever replace her love and he's all she needs because together they can \\"touch the stars above\\" because their love is heavent sent. I wouldn't classify \\"Joy Ride\\" as album filler but it's not one of the standout tracks on this album. The gospel tinged \\"Fly Like A Bird\\" finishes off the album for Mariah, who ask the big guy upstairs to carry her higher because of the tough times she is going through. The song is infused with the soul and passion expected on a gospel number and Mariah sings through this song with grace and ease never making her voice sound forced. Her plea to God is surprisingly convincing aided by the choir in the backround and the beating drums.  <br /> <br />\\"TheEmancipation of Mimi\\" doesn't offer anything groundbreaking in Mariahs career however it's a consistent and well crafted pop-R&B album and her best to come out since the other emancipation she went through that we called \\"Butterfly\\".  Ms. Carey doesn't have to blaze trails or break boundaries at this stage in her career, because she's already done that with her ballads, and hip hop and dance remixes. Her vocal  influence is written all over todays up and coming divas such as Christina Aguilera and Kelly Clarkson as well as every contestant on American Idol. If anything \\"Mimi\\" is a testament to longevity. After 15 years in the industry the best selling female artist of all time has prooved hat no matter what the hot trends are in music or whose on top (sorry J. Lo) a true talent such as Mariah can pair with the hot producers of today and put out quality material all while writing her own songs and holding an amazing note. <br /> <br />
